urn:contentItem:5P2D-C451-DY0W-44YY-00000-00Three GOP Senators To Vote No On Repealing Obamacare With Out Replacement; WH Takes On NAFTA; GOP Short Of Votes Needed To Debate Repeal2017-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:36ZLexisNexisThree GOP Senators To Vote No On Repealing Obamacare With Out Replacement; WH Takes On NAFTA; GOP Short Of Votes Needed To Debate RepealLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: -- through all of this which is remarkable.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Well, it is remarkable, Neil. Actually, it's very remarkable but well that hold up.

CAVUTO: No, I hear you, I hear you.

CASONE: That is the question. Neil Cavuto, thank you so much and --

CAVUTO: You got it.

CASONE: Neil was just telling you. Again, we are waiting to hear from Senate leaders to talk more about what is happening with the fate of health care, I mean reform at this point, looks really uncertain and particular at this hour.

The Senate's effort for clean and repeal of Obamacare really is failing so further receive enough support from Senate Republic and some big (INAUDIBLE), you know him well.

Neil is just talking about the submarkets, you know, Dow is down about 71 points right now. You know, we started the session with better numbers than this. So obviously investors are waiting to see, the more you delay health care, the more you delay tax reform investors are going to, at some point, maybe sooner rather than later say OK as enough of this. But for now, the market is not, we're holding on but the Dow is down 72.

Well, hello everybody I am Cheryl Casone. And I'm in for Trish Regan today. I would like to welcome you to The Intelligence Report. Boy, there is a lot going on. A source close to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has just told Fox News the Senator plans to go forward with a vote to repeal Obamacare first even if that vote fails.

Right now, it appears McConnell is well short of the votes he needs to debate, even debate the repeal bill after three Republican senators said that they're not -- they are going to vote no. So we're going to talk about what is next for healthcare. We are all over that story. And again, we're waiting for Mitch McConnell.

Also this today, we're watching President Trump getting back to his America first agenda. The administration just unveiling a new NAFTA plan aimed at shrinking our trade deficit with Canada and with Mexico but how exactly is this going to happen? How is this going to work? We've got the Intel for you on that.

But first I want to go back to Washington with Adam Shapiro. I think boondoggle at this point might be the word in my head Adam, with regards to what's going on with McConnell in the Senate right now.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, it certainly raises the question about how does leadership control its members. I mean, you've got the three Senators. Let's show you the baseball cards of threes who actually killed the effort to repeal. You have Susan Collins of Maine. She would have been a no vote, not only to debate but also on repeal. She did that in 2015. But you also have Lisa Murkowski from Alaska. She wouldn't even vote to proceed to debate, so she is a no. And then of course there's Shelley Moore Capito from West Virginia, she was a no. That was all it took but as you said there's an effort to perhaps maneuver this into a vote, just put everyone on the record and then move on.

It was President Trump though, who said, look, the Republicans are not going to own this. This is going to be on the Democrats. Here is what he said just about an hour ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF UNITED STATES: Let Obamacare fail, it will be a lot easier. And I think we're probably in that position where we'll just let Obamacare fail. We're not going to own it. I'm not going to own it. I can tell you the Republicans are not going to own it. We'll let Obamacare fail and then the Democrats are going to come to us and they're going to say how do we fix it, how do we fix it or how do we come up with a new plan.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: Well, the Democrats say they're open to working with Republicans on a fix but it can't include a repeal. So here is what Chuck Schumer, the minority leader said just moments ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHUCK SCHUMER, SENATE MINORITY LEADER: Republicans propose surgery. The operation was a failure. Now Republicans are proposing a second surgery that will surely kill the patient. Medicine is needed, bipartisan medicine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: So there seems to be agreement that the Affordable Care Act, Obamacare is not working, it needs to be fixed but getting these two sides together to fix it, good luck. Cheryl, back to you.

CASONE: Well, luck is really needed especially if you're Mitch McConnell right now. And we're waiting to hear from him Adam. Thank you for all the details on that.

You know, let's bring in for more analysis on all of this Republican Strategist, Ashley Hayek, Communications Director for Democracy in America -- for America. Excuse me, Neil Sroka and the Senior Writer at The Weekly Standard, John McCormack is here as well.

Guys, thank you so much for your time. So I mean this is, John, this is pretty wild what we're seeing going on. I mean, you talked about draining the swamp but Mitch McConnell seems to be losing more and more support every day. Is what we're going to see happen with the President just said just let it fail, let Obamacare fail, let it be done?

JOHN MCCORMACK, SENIOR WRITER OF THE WEEKLY STANDARD: You know, that's going to be really tough because what people seem to forget is that Obamacare is basically now synonymous with the individual insurance market. Remember, like your plan, you keep your plan, well that wasn't true. So people who are on the individual market, almost everyone in there have been affected by these very costly, very burdensome regulations. And, you know, to see Obamacare kind of go on and on to death spiral.

Listen, if totally true that this is being caused by bad legislation's passed by Democrats, but I think the voters are going to expect Republicans to get their act together, to actually fix the problem. And so I don't think they can really move on -- they might want to move on from healthcare but healthcare is not going to move on from them.

CASONE: Well, I mean, you know, this was something, Ashley, that the President wanted to see first. Let's do health care then we move to tax reform. Obviously, you know, in this tax reform in jeopardy, that is one question here but Ashley, at the same time, can they get anything done with regards to reform? If they can't even repeal it, does that mean that we have nothing, Ashley, on the table?

ASHLEY HAYEK, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Well, here is the problem, first and foremost, is the self-proclaimed conservatives. When premiums go up, they are going to cause a lot of things but these Republicans are not going to be called conservatives. And the next item absolutely tax reform. And if they can't get tax reform done, the base is going to lose. They're going to lose their stuff.

And one thing that dictates all of this is the market, the market, 17 percent, the market bought into -- in the economy and the market bought into the idea that our economy will do better with the repeal of Obamacare, cutting back on taxes. And when we're not able to repeal Obamacare, you're going to see effects long term. And it will come down to the seats in reelections.

CASONE: Neil, what do you make of the Republicans basically at this point, all signs reporting to failure to be able to do anything about Obamacare. We're not even talking Trumpcare, we're talking nothing, no movement, even if the repeal doesn't go anywhere, what does it point --

NEIL SROKA, COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR OF DEMOCRACY FOR AMERICA: I think what you're seeing right now is that Republicans are fundamentally unable to govern. They were able to run for eight years on something and now they can't even pull that together. The fact to the matter is, is reason why they can't vote to end Obamacare is because Obamacare is increasingly popular with the American people. You look at West Virginia and Alaska, two of the states that just killed this repeal effort, even though Donald Trump won handily in both of those states, both of those senators came out of this repeal bill because in those states, especially the Medicaid expansion portions of Obamacare are incredibly popular and needed.

CASONE: John, you cover Washington, you know, as journalist, I mean, I'm wondering if this is kind of, if politics as usual seems to be winning in all of this. And the reason I say that is because, you know, when President Trump came into office there was this feeling that you know, he was elected on wave of populism. People wanted to put the country first, repeal Obamacare, replace it, et cetera, get tax reform done. It seems to me that the politics seems to be overtaking policy in all of this today.

MCCORMACK: Well, I think there is something to that, you know, there is a lot of bias towards the status quo. Remember, Democrats passed this bill with 60 votes in the Senate, and overwhelmingly majority in the House and President who won by very large margin. Republicans come in with much smaller majority and so it's a lot tougher to reverse this, once it's already in effect.

And Republicans also, you got to remember, you know, the President didn't run on the specific repeal and replace agenda, the House of Representatives and the senators, they also didn't have really specific idea in mind what they could come up with. And so you basically have both conservatives and moderates unhappy as well as all these procedural roadblocks. You know, there be special rules they have to abide by. President Trump was right when he said that it's much more difficult to pass this bill with these special rules rather than getting 60 votes as Democrats did back in 2009 and 2010.

SROKA: No.

CASONE: Go ahead, Neil.

SROKA: I'm sorry. Donald Trump right now is an impotent as leader of the Republican Party if he can't even get Republicans on board to repeal and replace Obamacare, something that Republicans have been running on close to a decade. The reality is, is Republicans care far more about tax cuts for millionaires and billionaires than they do about the lives of American people. And that's ultimately why they don't want to do anything on Obamacare.

CASONE: You know, Neil, I got to push back on that. You can never underestimate the power of Donald Trump. I mean he was underestimated as candidate.

SROKA: Agreed.

CASONE: He is -- he's when it comes to world politics or what's happening here at home. That's the thing, Ashley. You know, this President, we know he's going to barnstorm America, he has going to all across this country to fight for tax reform. Something many believe at least on Wall Street, he should have done first. But, you know, let's spilt milk at this point, Ashley. But he's going to go out and take it to the people for tax reform. Is that his win, not health care?

HAYEK: Tax reform is completely separate from healthcare. I think he has a huge opportunity here in that it's a fresh plate. And he also has the opportunity to expand tax credits that's going to help the middle and working class. It can help economic growth and is going to help small businesses grow. And that's going to ultimately help our economy.

SROKA: There's a reason --

HAYEK: They're going back to my initial point, is that yes, these senators had seven years to come up with a new plan. From day one President Trump has said we have to repeal Obamacare. And what the senators especially those so self-proclaimed conservative senators have done is absolutely nothing. And it is on their hands. They should have had something since they have had seven years to complain about it.

CASONE: Guys we're out of time but I think, you know, bipartisan way we can all agree that this is pretty much a mess. And that's a mess that the blame does fall, you got to say on the Republicans.

And again, we're waiting for Mitch McConnell. We'll see what he has to say about all of this. Maybe he can --he's got a trick up his he sleeve, we don't know yet. But at this point things aren't looking real good for this. Ashley, Neil, John, really appreciate your time today.

HAYEK: Thank you.

MCCORMACK: Thanks.

CASONE: All right. Well, joining me now with his thoughts on health care, former Health and Human Services Deputy Secretary, and Former President of Lilly USA, Alex Azar. Alex, what do you make of what you're seeing in Washington? It seems to be a mess from those of us watching from the sidelines right now?

ALEX AZAR, FORMER U.S. HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES DEPUTY SECRETARY: Well, it's an absolute mess, you're right. I'm astonished to that. It does appear that the Republican House and Senate will not pass anything even with the label repeal of Obamacare on it. That's going to be a tough road in 2018 as they go back to their core voters having to explain that. Bit I think McConnell may now still call a vote on straight repeal just as matter of accountability with members of his caucus.

CASONE: Sure.

AZAR: Just make them put it on record, so it's not cost-free. But I really think that there is not going to be legislative action at this point.

CASONE: OK --

AZAR: I mean, the hot potato has landed in Secretary Tom Price's lap.

CASONE: Yes, well, and that's -- here is the thing. I'm curious, what can Tom Price do? That is the question, if he is going to be left with Obamacare which the President and which many analysts say is failing, will fail, what can Price do so that you don't have millions of Americans left with nothing, sick Americans? That's the concern I think from a human perspective in all of this?

AZAR: So let's separate the two programs. On the Medicaid side you have got Seema Verma running CMS who's one of the leaders in reinventing Medicaid. I think you see increasing state flexibility change, devolution to states there on Medicaid.

On the individual insurance market side there's going to be a debate in the administration right now. The President said let it fail I don't know fully what that means. There -- this program is failing because of inherently how the rate structure and the risk pooling was set up in it. So it's going to keep going down. The question is, does the administration actually pull the plug on to patient or they put it in hospice and try to make it a little better? There are things the secretary can do to actually save Obamacare from many of the very mistakes that Obama himself is and his administration imposed on the program.

CASONE: Would he -- we don't have a lot of time, but would he have the power to deal with lawsuits? And I say that because tort reform is something that so many were screaming about back in 2008 when this, when Obamacare was passed without half of Congress reading it, tort reform and maybe state to state competition for insurance companies. If you're going to have people in states with no exchanges, no options, is that something that Price can do from a legal perspective? I honestly don't know?

AZAR: I think very little the secretary can do in terms of tort reform actually lead those efforts for President Bush in his administration. Very little the President can do unilaterally without legislation there. And also interstate sale of insurance also, I think little the secretary can do but what he can do is grant waivers to states to create much more flexibility in his exchanges. I would do a top to bottom comprehensive rewrite of the regulations of Obamacare, imposing as much free market, localized flexibility as humanly possible. Even then the rate structure is just broken. And that's in the statute and that's not -- that he can't fix.

CASONE: Alex, I agree with you 100 percent. It's something I couldn't believe it wasn't in the first bill and here we are today with this mess that is these exchanges that are just falling apart. Alex, thank you very much.

AZAR: Great, thank you.

CASONE: Appreciate it.

Well, you know, the President has got a few things on the agenda. He is getting back to his America first agenda. He has outlined a new plan for renegotiating NAFTA. That was -- remember, one of his biggest campaign promises. But can he do it? We're going to talk about the legality of that, coming up next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Are we going to allow other countries to break the rules, steal our jobs and drain our wealth, and it has been drained, it has been drained.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Well, the White House unveiling its plan to update the decade old NAFTA deal following through on one of President Trump's biggest campaign promise.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: No longer are we going to allow other countries to break the rules, steal our jobs and drain our wealth. And it has been drained. It has been drained.

We're going to end up having a level playing field. I don't want to say anymore than a level but if the playing field we're slanted like a little bit toward us I would accept that also, OK?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: OK, I want (INAUDIBLE) right now. We want to take you live right now to Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky. He is speaking. Let's listen in.

RAND PAUL, (R) SENATOR, KENTUCKY: You saw what happened around here six years ago with the committee and that never worked up. There have been many ideas for how we get more people in our country insurance. For example, 27 million people don't have insurance right now under Obamacare. The estimates are that 50 percent of those 27 million don't get it because it's too expensive. It's too expensive because of the Obamacare regulations. The death spiral of Obamacare is regulations, make insurance expensive and then you say oh, but you can get it after you're sick. That is the real problem. That has the whole problem we have. It's the adverse selection and the death spiral. That's what we need to fix. We don't have enough votes to repeal all of that. So we're going to have to move forward. And I'm favor in moving forward with partial repeal and continuing to work on trying to get rid of the rest of the bad elements of that Obamacare that have driven prices up.

Thanks, guys.

(OFF-MIC)

PAUL: No, I'm for a vote that succeeds. And I think those Republicans who promised to repeal Obamacare ought to vote the same way they voted in 2015. If you're not willing to vote the same way you voted in 2015, then you need to go back home, you need to explain to Republicans why you're no longer for repealing Obamacare. Thanks.

CASONE: OK. So what he is saying basically, and this is what we learned earlier today is that Senator Mitch McConnell, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell does intend to hold a vote to proceed on straight repeal. OK, that's the questions that the reporters were asking of Senator Rand Paul. And he's -- that's what he has wanted entire time. He has been on Fox Business. He says on air saying, repeal. That is that, that is what he promised his constituency.

He also says, remember back in 2015, there was a move by the Senate to try and at least repeal some parts of Obamacare, do repeal President Barack Obama at the time though of course vetoed that. So it was kind of a symbolic move if you will by the Republicans.

Senators at the time, he is saying, hey, if the way that you voted in 2015 is how you feel, that's how you vote now. But remember, Senator Susan Collins, Senator Lisa Murkowski, they are saying no. They are not going to vote for repeal. They don't want to leave the American public with nothing. Many say though you repeal it, you give it couple of years, Senator Rand Paul saying this is a death spiral. The regulation, regulatory burdens of Obamacare which many analysts agree with is unacceptable for the American people.

I do want to bring in right now Nick Adams. He is the Founder and Executive Director of the Foundation for Liberty and American Greatness. You know, here's the thing, Nick. We're fighting back and forth about what to do and it comes down to politics versus policy. What we're seeing play out right now with these U.S. senators, the Republican Party is to me, politics as the midterms are approaching. What see you about that?

NICK ADAMS, FOUNDER AND EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF THE FOUNDATION FOR LIBERTY AND AMERICAN GREATNESS: Cheryl, look, you summed it up very well. It's definitely is a battle between politics and policy. There is absolutely no reason that the Republicans shouldn't be able to pass this. This is what they ran on. This is what they owe President Trump. And I think it's incredibly disappointing that we have so many Republicans that are just not coming to the table and not getting this done. And as a result I think this will have ramifications for future elections if they're not able to get together and do this.

CASONE: Well, that's why Senator Paul, not just now but earlier on Fox Business last week actually, had said, look, you know, I promised repeal. I'm not go back to my constituents if I'm not supporting repeal. The problem is McConnell is going to hold this vote. It's going to fail. So you're going to have the political backlash on the heads of these senators.

It would seem to me that at this point we're going to have nothing versus something. Now, politically that hurts the Republicans, yes?

ADAMS: Yes, that's right. And it's just amazing that it has come to this, Cheryl. I mean, they have had so long. They have had so much time. They've had such opportunity to prepare for this. And here we are. We went through this earlier this year. We're at this point again. And it's just tragic to see the Republicans perpetually snatch defeat from the jaws of victory. And I think the American people have every right to be incredibly disappointed by the display that the Republicans are putting on.

They're showing themselves to be Lily Livered. They're showing themselves to have jellyfish backs and really President Trump has got to be absolutely wringing his hands here because he's got some Republicans that were elected really on back of his popularity that are just not doing the right thing.

urn:contentItem:5P2D-CPG1-DY0W-44KN-00000-00Three GOP Senators To Vote No On Repealing Obamacare With Out Replacement; WH Takes On NAFTA; GOP Short Of Votes Needed To Debate Repeal2017-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:36ZLexisNexisThree GOP Senators To Vote No On Repealing Obamacare With Out Replacement; WH Takes On NAFTA; GOP Short Of Votes Needed To Debate RepealLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: -- through all of this which is remarkable.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Well, it is remarkable, Neil. Actually, it's very remarkable but well that hold up.

CAVUTO: No, I hear you, I hear you.

CASONE: That is the question. Neil Cavuto, thank you so much and --

CAVUTO: You got it.

CASONE: Neil was just telling you. Again, we are waiting to hear from Senate leaders to talk more about what is happening with the fate of health care, I mean reform at this point, looks really uncertain and particular at this hour.

The Senate's effort for clean and repeal of Obamacare really is failing so further receive enough support from Senate Republic and some big (INAUDIBLE), you know him well.

Neil is just talking about the submarkets, you know, Dow is down about 71 points right now. You know, we started the session with better numbers than this. So obviously investors are waiting to see, the more you delay health care, the more you delay tax reform investors are going to, at some point, maybe sooner rather than later say OK as enough of this. But for now, the market is not, we're holding on but the Dow is down 72.

Well, hello everybody I am Cheryl Casone. And I'm in for Trish Regan today. I would like to welcome you to The Intelligence Report. Boy, there is a lot going on. A source close to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has just told Fox News the Senator plans to go forward with a vote to repeal Obamacare first even if that vote fails.

Right now, it appears McConnell is well short of the votes he needs to debate, even debate the repeal bill after three Republican senators said that they're not -- they are going to vote no. So we're going to talk about what is next for healthcare. We are all over that story. And again, we're waiting for Mitch McConnell.

Also this today, we're watching President Trump getting back to his America first agenda. The administration just unveiling a new NAFTA plan aimed at shrinking our trade deficit with Canada and with Mexico but how exactly is this going to happen? How is this going to work? We've got the Intel for you on that.

But first I want to go back to Washington with Adam Shapiro. I think boondoggle at this point might be the word in my head Adam, with regards to what's going on with McConnell in the Senate right now.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Well, it certainly raises the question about how does leadership control its members. I mean, you've got the three Senators. Let's show you the baseball cards of threes who actually killed the effort to repeal. You have Susan Collins of Maine. She would have been a no vote, not only to debate but also on repeal. She did that in 2015. But you also have Lisa Murkowski from Alaska. She wouldn't even vote to proceed to debate, so she is a no. And then of course there's Shelley Moore Capito from West Virginia, she was a no. That was all it took but as you said there's an effort to perhaps maneuver this into a vote, just put everyone on the record and then move on.

It was President Trump though, who said, look, the Republicans are not going to own this. This is going to be on the Democrats. Here is what he said just about an hour ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF UNITED STATES: Let Obamacare fail, it will be a lot easier. And I think we're probably in that position where we'll just let Obamacare fail. We're not going to own it. I'm not going to own it. I can tell you the Republicans are not going to own it. We'll let Obamacare fail and then the Democrats are going to come to us and they're going to say how do we fix it, how do we fix it or how do we come up with a new plan.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: Well, the Democrats say they're open to working with Republicans on a fix but it can't include a repeal. So here is what Chuck Schumer, the minority leader said just moments ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHUCK SCHUMER, SENATE MINORITY LEADER: Republicans propose surgery. The operation was a failure. Now Republicans are proposing a second surgery that will surely kill the patient. Medicine is needed, bipartisan medicine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: So there seems to be agreement that the Affordable Care Act, Obamacare is not working, it needs to be fixed but getting these two sides together to fix it, good luck. Cheryl, back to you.

CASONE: Well, luck is really needed especially if you're Mitch McConnell right now. And we're waiting to hear from him Adam. Thank you for all the details on that.

You know, let's bring in for more analysis on all of this Republican Strategist, Ashley Hayek, Communications Director for Democracy in America -- for America. Excuse me, Neil Sroka and the Senior Writer at The Weekly Standard, John McCormack is here as well.

Guys, thank you so much for your time. So I mean this is, John, this is pretty wild what we're seeing going on. I mean, you talked about draining the swamp but Mitch McConnell seems to be losing more and more support every day. Is what we're going to see happen with the President just said just let it fail, let Obamacare fail, let it be done?

JOHN MCCORMACK, SENIOR WRITER OF THE WEEKLY STANDARD: You know, that's going to be really tough because what people seem to forget is that Obamacare is basically now synonymous with the individual insurance market. Remember, like your plan, you keep your plan, well that wasn't true. So people who are on the individual market, almost everyone in there have been affected by these very costly, very burdensome regulations. And, you know, to see Obamacare kind of go on and on to death spiral.

Listen, if totally true that this is being caused by bad legislation's passed by Democrats, but I think the voters are going to expect Republicans to get their act together, to actually fix the problem. And so I don't think they can really move on -- they might want to move on from healthcare but healthcare is not going to move on from them.

CASONE: Well, I mean, you know, this was something, Ashley, that the President wanted to see first. Let's do health care then we move to tax reform. Obviously, you know, in this tax reform in jeopardy, that is one question here but Ashley, at the same time, can they get anything done with regards to reform? If they can't even repeal it, does that mean that we have nothing, Ashley, on the table?

ASHLEY HAYEK, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Well, here is the problem, first and foremost, is the self-proclaimed conservatives. When premiums go up, they are going to cause a lot of things but these Republicans are not going to be called conservatives. And the next item absolutely tax reform. And if they can't get tax reform done, the base is going to lose. They're going to lose their stuff.

And one thing that dictates all of this is the market, the market, 17 percent, the market bought into -- in the economy and the market bought into the idea that our economy will do better with the repeal of Obamacare, cutting back on taxes. And when we're not able to repeal Obamacare, you're going to see effects long term. And it will come down to the seats in reelections.

CASONE: Neil, what do you make of the Republicans basically at this point, all signs reporting to failure to be able to do anything about Obamacare. We're not even talking Trumpcare, we're talking nothing, no movement, even if the repeal doesn't go anywhere, what does it point --

NEIL SROKA, COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR OF DEMOCRACY FOR AMERICA: I think what you're seeing right now is that Republicans are fundamentally unable to govern. They were able to run for eight years on something and now they can't even pull that together. The fact to the matter is, is reason why they can't vote to end Obamacare is because Obamacare is increasingly popular with the American people. You look at West Virginia and Alaska, two of the states that just killed this repeal effort, even though Donald Trump won handily in both of those states, both of those senators came out of this repeal bill because in those states, especially the Medicaid expansion portions of Obamacare are incredibly popular and needed.

CASONE: John, you cover Washington, you know, as journalist, I mean, I'm wondering if this is kind of, if politics as usual seems to be winning in all of this. And the reason I say that is because, you know, when President Trump came into office there was this feeling that you know, he was elected on wave of populism. People wanted to put the country first, repeal Obamacare, replace it, et cetera, get tax reform done. It seems to me that the politics seems to be overtaking policy in all of this today.

MCCORMACK: Well, I think there is something to that, you know, there is a lot of bias towards the status quo. Remember, Democrats passed this bill with 60 votes in the Senate, and overwhelmingly majority in the House and President who won by very large margin. Republicans come in with much smaller majority and so it's a lot tougher to reverse this, once it's already in effect.

And Republicans also, you got to remember, you know, the President didn't run on the specific repeal and replace agenda, the House of Representatives and the senators, they also didn't have really specific idea in mind what they could come up with. And so you basically have both conservatives and moderates unhappy as well as all these procedural roadblocks. You know, there be special rules they have to abide by. President Trump was right when he said that it's much more difficult to pass this bill with these special rules rather than getting 60 votes as Democrats did back in 2009 and 2010.

SROKA: No.

CASONE: Go ahead, Neil.

SROKA: I'm sorry. Donald Trump right now is an impotent as leader of the Republican Party if he can't even get Republicans on board to repeal and replace Obamacare, something that Republicans have been running on close to a decade. The reality is, is Republicans care far more about tax cuts for millionaires and billionaires than they do about the lives of American people. And that's ultimately why they don't want to do anything on Obamacare.

CASONE: You know, Neil, I got to push back on that. You can never underestimate the power of Donald Trump. I mean he was underestimated as candidate.

SROKA: Agreed.

CASONE: He is -- he's when it comes to world politics or what's happening here at home. That's the thing, Ashley. You know, this President, we know he's going to barnstorm America, he has going to all across this country to fight for tax reform. Something many believe at least on Wall Street, he should have done first. But, you know, let's spilt milk at this point, Ashley. But he's going to go out and take it to the people for tax reform. Is that his win, not health care?

HAYEK: Tax reform is completely separate from healthcare. I think he has a huge opportunity here in that it's a fresh plate. And he also has the opportunity to expand tax credits that's going to help the middle and working class. It can help economic growth and is going to help small businesses grow. And that's going to ultimately help our economy.

SROKA: There's a reason --

HAYEK: They're going back to my initial point, is that yes, these senators had seven years to come up with a new plan. From day one President Trump has said we have to repeal Obamacare. And what the senators especially those so self-proclaimed conservative senators have done is absolutely nothing. And it is on their hands. They should have had something since they have had seven years to complain about it.

CASONE: Guys we're out of time but I think, you know, bipartisan way we can all agree that this is pretty much a mess. And that's a mess that the blame does fall, you got to say on the Republicans.

And again, we're waiting for Mitch McConnell. We'll see what he has to say about all of this. Maybe he can --he's got a trick up his he sleeve, we don't know yet. But at this point things aren't looking real good for this. Ashley, Neil, John, really appreciate your time today.

HAYEK: Thank you.

MCCORMACK: Thanks.

CASONE: All right. Well, joining me now with his thoughts on health care, former Health and Human Services Deputy Secretary, and Former President of Lilly USA, Alex Azar. Alex, what do you make of what you're seeing in Washington? It seems to be a mess from those of us watching from the sidelines right now?

ALEX AZAR, FORMER U.S. HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES DEPUTY SECRETARY: Well, it's an absolute mess, you're right. I'm astonished to that. It does appear that the Republican House and Senate will not pass anything even with the label repeal of Obamacare on it. That's going to be a tough road in 2018 as they go back to their core voters having to explain that. Bit I think McConnell may now still call a vote on straight repeal just as matter of accountability with members of his caucus.

CASONE: Sure.

AZAR: Just make them put it on record, so it's not cost-free. But I really think that there is not going to be legislative action at this point.

CASONE: OK --

AZAR: I mean, the hot potato has landed in Secretary Tom Price's lap.

CASONE: Yes, well, and that's -- here is the thing. I'm curious, what can Tom Price do? That is the question, if he is going to be left with Obamacare which the President and which many analysts say is failing, will fail, what can Price do so that you don't have millions of Americans left with nothing, sick Americans? That's the concern I think from a human perspective in all of this?

AZAR: So let's separate the two programs. On the Medicaid side you have got Seema Verma running CMS who's one of the leaders in reinventing Medicaid. I think you see increasing state flexibility change, devolution to states there on Medicaid.

On the individual insurance market side there's going to be a debate in the administration right now. The President said let it fail I don't know fully what that means. There -- this program is failing because of inherently how the rate structure and the risk pooling was set up in it. So it's going to keep going down. The question is, does the administration actually pull the plug on to patient or they put it in hospice and try to make it a little better? There are things the secretary can do to actually save Obamacare from many of the very mistakes that Obama himself is and his administration imposed on the program.

CASONE: Would he -- we don't have a lot of time, but would he have the power to deal with lawsuits? And I say that because tort reform is something that so many were screaming about back in 2008 when this, when Obamacare was passed without half of Congress reading it, tort reform and maybe state to state competition for insurance companies. If you're going to have people in states with no exchanges, no options, is that something that Price can do from a legal perspective? I honestly don't know?

AZAR: I think very little the secretary can do in terms of tort reform actually lead those efforts for President Bush in his administration. Very little the President can do unilaterally without legislation there. And also interstate sale of insurance also, I think little the secretary can do but what he can do is grant waivers to states to create much more flexibility in his exchanges. I would do a top to bottom comprehensive rewrite of the regulations of Obamacare, imposing as much free market, localized flexibility as humanly possible. Even then the rate structure is just broken. And that's in the statute and that's not -- that he can't fix.

CASONE: Alex, I agree with you 100 percent. It's something I couldn't believe it wasn't in the first bill and here we are today with this mess that is these exchanges that are just falling apart. Alex, thank you very much.

AZAR: Great, thank you.

CASONE: Appreciate it.

Well, you know, the President has got a few things on the agenda. He is getting back to his America first agenda. He has outlined a new plan for renegotiating NAFTA. That was -- remember, one of his biggest campaign promises. But can he do it? We're going to talk about the legality of that, coming up next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Are we going to allow other countries to break the rules, steal our jobs and drain our wealth, and it has been drained, it has been drained.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Well, the White House unveiling its plan to update the decade old NAFTA deal following through on one of President Trump's biggest campaign promise.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: No longer are we going to allow other countries to break the rules, steal our jobs and drain our wealth. And it has been drained. It has been drained.

We're going to end up having a level playing field. I don't want to say anymore than a level but if the playing field we're slanted like a little bit toward us I would accept that also, OK?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: OK, I want (INAUDIBLE) right now. We want to take you live right now to Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky. He is speaking. Let's listen in.

RAND PAUL, (R) SENATOR, KENTUCKY: You saw what happened around here six years ago with the committee and that never worked up. There have been many ideas for how we get more people in our country insurance. For example, 27 million people don't have insurance right now under Obamacare. The estimates are that 50 percent of those 27 million don't get it because it's too expensive. It's too expensive because of the Obamacare regulations. The death spiral of Obamacare is regulations, make insurance expensive and then you say oh, but you can get it after you're sick. That is the real problem. That has the whole problem we have. It's the adverse selection and the death spiral. That's what we need to fix. We don't have enough votes to repeal all of that. So we're going to have to move forward. And I'm favor in moving forward with partial repeal and continuing to work on trying to get rid of the rest of the bad elements of that Obamacare that have driven prices up.

Thanks, guys.

(OFF-MIC)

PAUL: No, I'm for a vote that succeeds. And I think those Republicans who promised to repeal Obamacare ought to vote the same way they voted in 2015. If you're not willing to vote the same way you voted in 2015, then you need to go back home, you need to explain to Republicans why you're no longer for repealing Obamacare. Thanks.

CASONE: OK. So what he is saying basically, and this is what we learned earlier today is that Senator Mitch McConnell, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell does intend to hold a vote to proceed on straight repeal. OK, that's the questions that the reporters were asking of Senator Rand Paul. And he's -- that's what he has wanted entire time. He has been on Fox Business. He says on air saying, repeal. That is that, that is what he promised his constituency.

He also says, remember back in 2015, there was a move by the Senate to try and at least repeal some parts of Obamacare, do repeal President Barack Obama at the time though of course vetoed that. So it was kind of a symbolic move if you will by the Republicans.

Senators at the time, he is saying, hey, if the way that you voted in 2015 is how you feel, that's how you vote now. But remember, Senator Susan Collins, Senator Lisa Murkowski, they are saying no. They are not going to vote for repeal. They don't want to leave the American public with nothing. Many say though you repeal it, you give it couple of years, Senator Rand Paul saying this is a death spiral. The regulation, regulatory burdens of Obamacare which many analysts agree with is unacceptable for the American people.

I do want to bring in right now Nick Adams. He is the Founder and Executive Director of the Foundation for Liberty and American Greatness. You know, here's the thing, Nick. We're fighting back and forth about what to do and it comes down to politics versus policy. What we're seeing play out right now with these U.S. senators, the Republican Party is to me, politics as the midterms are approaching. What see you about that?

NICK ADAMS, FOUNDER AND EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF THE FOUNDATION FOR LIBERTY AND AMERICAN GREATNESS: Cheryl, look, you summed it up very well. It's definitely is a battle between politics and policy. There is absolutely no reason that the Republicans shouldn't be able to pass this. This is what they ran on. This is what they owe President Trump. And I think it's incredibly disappointing that we have so many Republicans that are just not coming to the table and not getting this done. And as a result I think this will have ramifications for future elections if they're not able to get together and do this.

CASONE: Well, that's why Senator Paul, not just now but earlier on Fox Business last week actually, had said, look, you know, I promised repeal. I'm not go back to my constituents if I'm not supporting repeal. The problem is McConnell is going to hold this vote. It's going to fail. So you're going to have the political backlash on the heads of these senators.

It would seem to me that at this point we're going to have nothing versus something. Now, politically that hurts the Republicans, yes?

ADAMS: Yes, that's right. And it's just amazing that it has come to this, Cheryl. I mean, they have had so long. They have had so much time. They've had such opportunity to prepare for this. And here we are. We went through this earlier this year. We're at this point again. And it's just tragic to see the Republicans perpetually snatch defeat from the jaws of victory. And I think the American people have every right to be incredibly disappointed by the display that the Republicans are putting on.

They're showing themselves to be Lily Livered. They're showing themselves to have jellyfish backs and really President Trump has got to be absolutely wringing his hands here because he's got some Republicans that were elected really on back of his popularity that are just not doing the right thing.

CASONE: You know, and it's true, and I think that the President is making it very clear that it is on the shoulders of those they are failing to support Republican efforts to repeal, replace or just repeal Obamacare.

Before I let you go, obviously, we are a business network. And investors have been -- these markets have been hitting record after record. Twenty- five records I think now for the Dow. I might be wrong. I men, that is an incredible streak for these markets. But the fear now, that ends when we finally see that the Trump agenda is in trouble. At what point do you think we hit that marker, Nick?

ADAMS: Well, look, Cheryl, I wouldn't be too worried right now. I think it's still time to be popping champagne, corks and the like. I think that we've got a president here who's been the best President since Ronald Reagan. I think that we've got a president that's putting Americans first. I think the markets are going to continue to respond to that. I suspect confidence, consumer confidence, constituent confidence, is all going to continue to rise. So I wouldn't be expecting any kind of change anytime soon.

CASONE: An Australian guy that believes in the American dream. Nick, it's always great to have you on the show. Thank you.

ADAMS: Always a pleasure, Cheryl Casone.

CASONE: Nick Adams, of course, who we should say is an American citizen now. Thank you, Nick. Great to have you on.

All right. We'll talk about the markets. You know, look, there are the health care stocks that we're watching like United Health Group. OK, they came out with earnings this morning that they're out of the exchanges but, you know, look, anything that happens with regards to health care, Obamacare will affect all names we're seeing on your screen. Aetna and Cigna, Humana is down, United Health Group, low, bucking the trend but that is piece we should say of earnings coming up this morning.

Take a look at Netflix, blowout quarter for that stock last night, jumped 10 percent. Now, it's up 14 percent right now. You just can't stop Netflix. Subscriber growth internationally, domestically really killing it for Netflix. This stock is on a roll, up more than 23 bucks right now.

We're going to be talking about your money when we come back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Turmoil over healthcare putting pressure on our markets. Investors are concerned about what this all is going to mean for the Trump administration's plans for tax reform and other pro-growth initiatives. All of this as Bank of America and Goldman Sachs are dragging on the markets after they reported earnings this morning, both of the banks trading pressure, investment banking pressure of Goldman Sachs. All of that factoring in of course and then the Fed interest rates kind of help Bank of America but not enough.

Let's bring in for analysis, Belpointe Asset Management Chief Strategist David Nelson. He is here in our studio, Lori Rothman down on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Lori, to you first, about the bank numbers.

LORI ROTHMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Right. OK. So it's kind of a surprise from Goldman Sachs, Cheryl. So Financial is because of this disappointing Goldman numbers are leading the S&P lower at this hour. Forty percent decline in trading revenue. Now for Goldman Sachs, trading will mean that's the bread and butter. That's what they're known for, right? So, that kind of decline is pretty shocking.

Bank of America on the other hand, did OK. Rising interest rates really helping the Bank of America because, you know, they have a lot interest rate sensitive, mortgage holdings also a lot of consumer deposits. So higher rates mean more profit for a company like Bank of America. There, you see those shares are down half a percent, likely being dragged lower by brother (ph) weakness as I mentioned in Goldman Sachs.

And of course, the big picture today which this healthcare gridlock in Washington. All right here on the floor, zeroed in on the Trump administration and what is going to happen next with healthcare. And down the road what it means for the Trump administration's plans for tax reform, infrastructure spending. I mean, it's very interesting, right? You've got materials names, energy names all lower because of that concerns that we won't get this economic shot in the arm that the President had been talking about with the latest hiccup in healthcare, Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes. And, you know, Lori, you bring up the point about growth, you know, economic growth. And David, that's the concern here. You know, you've got particularly Gary Cohn has been saying it very clear, you know, we're going to get, you know, more than two percent growth, three percent growth, you know, that GDP number that you're seeing from Gary Cohn, the Economic Adviser to the President.

DAVID NELSON, ASSET MANAGEMENT CHIEF STRATEGIST, BELPOINTE: Yes.

CASONE: But a lot are questioning if those growth, those projections can be doable if you don't have, you know, what's happening in Congress if you don't have healthcare or tax reform at all.

NELSON: OK. But on the other side of that, Cheryl, I think for a lot of portfolio managers like myself, all the way back when the healthcare vote failed in the House the first time. We kind of understood that it was going to be a long slog, and that the agenda from the administration was going to take a lot longer than initially we had thought.

I kind of thought it was a mistake to leave with healthcare. I thought tax reform was the better way to go. It certainly had some bipartisan support. And even Jamie Dimon spoke about that on the conference call last Friday.

CASONE: Yes.

NELSON: How uncompetitive corporate rates are. Well, basically, offshoring or manufacturing or cash flow. And in some cases, we're actually are destroying the company themselves and with the financial engineering like an inversion.

CASONE: Yes. But really quick, David, with Goldman Sachs, there is movement. We're going to talk about this later.

NELSON: Sure.

CASONE: There's movement in the House to put through at the budget proposal

NELSON: Yes.

CASONE: But within it, there's some regulatory proposals that would actually push through tax reform. I don't want to get in the weeds because I don't want to put our viewers to sleep. It's incredibly boring. But, I mean, this could be the savior for tax reform.

NELSON: It could be at least a start, and I think they're going to have to approach this on an incremental level. Look, the tax code is 77,000 pages. Unwinding it in a broad sweeping bill, that's going to take some time.

CASONE: Yes. Bring on Paul Ryan. More pressure for him, Lori. But, you know, that's the thing in investors and traders on the floor of they exchange. Obviously, if we get down to -- I don't know, maybe October, November and we don't have anything pushing through on tax reform, I'm wondering if that's when you're going to see the volume pick up and that's going to be selling pressure.

ROTHMAN: So, you know, don't forget, Cheryl, it's been months, right, since Wall Street has been hinging so much of its confidence on what comes out of the administration. In the meantime, don't forget we have had some pretty good earnings, some pretty good economic news, broader picture right in the middle of earnings season.

You know, I was talking earlier about the mixed of report from the Financials but, you know, we're going to hear from some of the big tech heavyweights tonight on IBM. Of course, I'm forgetting to even remind you about Netflix blowing away the street last night, Netflix alone.

CASONE: Oh, I'm all over it.

ROTHMAN: It is keeping the Nasdaq in record territory. I mean, Nasdaq is poised supposed in the record.

CASONE: I'm so sorry, Lori, we've got to go back to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell speaking on Capitol Hill. Let's listen to him.

MITCH MCCONNELL, (R-KY) SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: -- to vote for a replacement for Obamacare. Consequently, sometime in the near future, we'll have a vote on repealing Obamacare, essentially, the same vote that we had in 2015.

I would remind everyone that, in that proposal, there's a two-year delay, a two-year delay, which would give us the opportunity to work out a complete replacement on a bipartisan basis with our Democratic friends.

So, that's a vote I think we're very likely to have in the very near future.

JOHN CORNYN III, (R) SENATOR, TEXAS: We've got a sense of what the future might look like if we are unsuccessful in repealing and replacing Obamacare. We saw for the second time in a few days, Democratic senators coming to the floor asking for tens of billions of dollars and tax dollars for insurance company bailouts. No reform, no change in the status quo. And after seven years I think we can safely conclude that the structure of Obamacare is a failed experiment.

That's why we want to change the structure of the healthcare delivery system as we stabilize markets, protect people from premium increases and preexisting condition exclusions. We're going to continue down that road because the alternative, I fear, is going to be a Democratic effort strictly to bail out insurance companies with no reform whatsoever.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: After seven years of Obamacare, the American public knows what they have. They have fewer choices. They have higher premiums and less control over their own healthcare. Number of years ago, I voted to do a repeal of the Obama health care law. I'm ready to make that complete repeal vote again.

But, of course, that's not enough, the people of Wyoming want more than that. They want to be able to buy the insurance that they want that works right for them, not what the federal government in Washington, D.C. says they have to buy. So, I'm ready to vote to repeal.

We need a medical system not just as good as it was before Obamacare was passed but we need a medical system and a healthcare system in the country even better than that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think the only thing I could add in this discussion is at some point we need to figure out and find out where the votes are. This is an important work to be done. It affects families. It affects health care. We need to find out where the votes are. But there are other things we need to do too.

The President this week is talking about manufacturing made in America, if you could pay the utility bill, if the transportation system works. Those are the two boxes you check when you start talking about jobs. We all know the best place to get an insurance is still at work where somebody else does negotiations, somebody else reads the policy. Ways that more people could get insurance at work is important. Tax structure is important.

This has had a considerable amount of time spent on it, and sooner rather than later we need to find out where the Senate is and move forward.

CORY GARDNER, (R) SENATOR, COLORADO: There are a lot of people out there today who seem to be spiking the football, trying to celebrate a moment. But for now, it seems to leave the Affordable Care Act in place for today. But let me tell you what happens if you continue to spike the football. In the State of Colorado last week, it was announced the average premium rate increase for the next year will be 27 percent. But that's if you're lucky enough to live in the front range of Colorado.

If you live in the eastern plains or the western slope, you're going to pay 30 percent more. You're going to pay 40 percent more. That's spiking the football on the American people who will continue to pay more under the Affordable Care Act that is collapsing.

We will continue our work to get our job done to make sure that the status quo no longer stands and instead we provide relief to the American people.

MCCONNELL: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You went through an arrangement of your bill, and we've heard from some your members that they were very critical to process, and some were critical for Senator Johnson who was specifically critical so that reach the process. Do you feel that you and your leadership have been damaged in this process and that now you can actually -- after this across considering those criticisms that you heard?

MCCONNELL: Well, you know, this has been a very, very challenging experience for all of us. It's pretty obvious that we don't have 50 members who can agree on a replacement. A lot of people have been involved in the discussion and very passionate discussions.

But everybody is giving it their best shot. And as of today, we simply do not have 50 senators who can agree on what ought to replace the existing law. What we do have is a vote that many of us made two years ago, at the time when the President of the United States would not sign the legislation that would repeal Obamacare. And with a two-year delay give us an opportunity to build something better on a bipartisan basis. That's what I sense most of our members would like to vote on now, and we'll be doing that in the near future.

(CROSSTALK)

(OFF-MIC)

MCCONNELL: Nancy (ph).

NANCY: You don't appear currently to have the vote for that repeal and replace. If that vote fails, will you then begin working with Democrats?

MCCONNELL: Well, I think we'll have to see what happens. We will have demonstrated that Republicans by themselves are not prepared at this particular point to do a replacement. And that doesn't mean that the problems all go away, and you'll have to look at our committee chairman and their ranking members.

My suspicion is there will be hearings about the crisis that we have, and we'll have to see what the way forward is.

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (INAUDIBLE) and in seven months, that is wasted. There is no accomplishment. How can we explain this to voters next year if we don't do (INAUDIBLE)?

MCCONNELL: Well, we have a new Supreme Court Justice. We have 14 repeals of regulations, and we're only six months into it. Last time I looked, Congress goes on for two years. We'll be moving onto comprehensive tax reform and the infrastructure. There's much work left to be done for the American people and we're ready to tackle it. Thanks.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thanks a lot.

(OFF-MIC)

CASONE: We don't have the votes. That was Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell saying that they do not have 50 senators that can agree on what to replace Obamacare with. They all want to repeal it. Well, most of them do but the majority can't agree on the replacement.

In particular, he said -- and this is what Senator Cornyn said as well. You know, many of these senators wanted repeal. Cory Gardner is talking about the crisis in Colorado with the healthcare exchanges that, you know, each of the senators has to go home at some point in August and face constituents that are dealing with these healthcare exchanges that are frankly falling apart.

I want to say really quick here, and you mentioned tax reform when you look at the Dow really quick, when McConnell started to talk, the Dow was down more than 60 points. We're backing up that just a little bit. So, there's a little bit of a pullback but markets certainly are watching every single word that we get out of Washington. The word is we don't have the votes. Repeal and replace Obamacare is not going to happen.

All right. Let's bring back with me Patrice Lee Onwuka. She is a senior policy analyst at the Independent Women's Forum. David Nelson is still with me. Ashley Hayek and Neil Sroka are back as well. Guys, thank you very much for sticking around. Patrice, I want to go to you first. You know, at least he said, OK, next is tax reform.

What alarmed me though that McConnell just said at some point we're going to have hearings on Capitol Hill about the failure of Obamacare. My first reaction is was that going to cost the American taxpayer? Don't we need to just move on to tax reform?

PATRICE LEE ONWUKA, SENIOR POLICY ANALYST, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S FORUM: I mean, it would be ideal, 61 percent of Americans want their middle class tax break. They want a tax cuts. And so, I think it inspires confidence in the markets, in businesses and the American people when we can deliver something that going to stimulate the economy.

CASONE: You know, Neil, you had Senator Barrasso saying it, Senator Blunt saying it. They've got to have a conversation. They got to go back in within their ranks and figure out, Neil, what went wrong? But I know that you think a lot has gone wrong with the Republicans.

SROKA: Yes. And what went wrong is they had no plan at all. And let's be serious here. The tax reform plans that we're starting to hear come out of House are not a middle-class tax cut. They are a giant giveaway to millionaires, billionaires. And I think are going to cut social security, Medicare and Medicaid benefits potentially for millions of Americans.

So, if you want to talk about a tax plan that's going to be disastrous but they are overwhelming majority of American people. That's exactly what we're seeing, kind of --

CASONE: I don't agree with that. I know that David does not agree as well. I'm sorry, Neil.

NELSON: Yes I think this is exactly what I would expect from the left. It's an overreaction here. I think from the health care package -- on the health care package, look, Obamacare largely failed because it was owned only by the Democrats.

This failed because it's only owned by the Republicans. They're going to have to actually talk to each other. And I think that's what the American people expect. We going to have to sit down at the table and negotiate this out. Because just owning it on one side or the other isn't going to do it. Both sides need on.

SROKA: They spent seven months trying to have a conversation about health care. And the fact of the matter is Republicans do not have a plan.

NELSON: This was a plan. Obamacare was passed in the middle of the night. Give me a break.

CASONE: And I think we have --

SROKA: -- four months in open forums. I'm going to be really looking forward to seeing what the open discussions are like.

CASONE: OK.

SROKA: All across the country --

NELSON: So, let's hear it.

SROKA: --we got a brush fire of millions of Americans who hate everything that the Republican Party is proposing.

ONWUKA: Well, let me jump in and say here.

CASONE: All right. Well, I forgot. I'm so sorry. I want to listen to Senator Chuck Schumer, he's at podium. Stand by.

CHUCK SCHUMER, (D) SENATOR, NEW YORK: Thank you. And I'm proud to be joined by Senators Klobuchar and Heinrich.

Now, it's getting clearer and clearer that Senate Republicans won't be able to pass either their bill or a backup plan of repeal without replacement.

We Democrats believe that the time has finally come for our Republican colleagues to take us up on our offer of working together to improve the health care system rather than sabotage it. Evidently, President Trump is proposing a different path. He wants to throw up his hands rather than roll up his sleeves to work with us and solve the problem. But let's be very clear about what the President is proposing and where his path would lead.

The President would not be, "letting Obamacare collapse." He is actively, actively trying undermined the health care system in this country using millions of Americans as political pawns in a cynical game. By continuing to deny the insurance markets their certainty that they need to function, the President is playing a dangerous game with the health care of this country.

So our Republican colleagues here in the Senate have a choice to make. They can follow the President down a path that will lead to higher premiums, less care, and millions of Americans losing coverage. They can join President Trump in trying to sabotage the system and hurt millions of innocent Americans to try and make a political point that has failed already, or they can start today working with Democrats.

We can work together to lower premiums. We can work together to stabilize the markets. We can work together to improve the quality of health care. This isn't a radical idea. A group of 11 Republican and Democratic governors called for exactly the kind of bipartisan cooperation that we are calling for, a bipartisan group of governors.

We Democrats have held the door to bipartisanship open to our Republican colleagues for months. It's time for the Republicans to walk through it. Senator Klobuchar?

AMY KLOBUCHAR, (D) SENATOR, MINNESOTA: Thank you very much, Senator Schumer, and thank you so much for the work you've done.

CASONE: OK, we want to -- we break out really quick. Just want to recap here. We just heard from Senator Schumer, the time has come, basically. He's offering once again to work with the Republican leaders to come up with something that will fix. I mean there's one thing that we can see between the Democrats and Republicans. They both agree the exchanges are failing.

But do you let those fail with nothing to back up the American people that still require health care? Wanted to get to Senator Schumer's comments, is bipartisanship possible in all of this?

I want to back in our panel. I got Patrice Lee Onwuka with me as well as David Nelson is here, Ashley Hayek still with me, Neil Sroka is with me. He's got have something to say I'm sure. Also I want to bring in if we can, Gregg Jarrett from the Fox News Channel to talk about the legalities of all this. And Gregg welcome to you. First to you on this, what we're saying now is another olive branch from Schumer.

GREGG JARRETT, FOX NEWS CHANNEL: Right.

CASONE: On, you know, on the surface, anyway.

JARRETT: Well, he says the door is open, yes. It's open, but for only one thing. Do it our way or we won't cooperate with anything you want to do. So, it's not much of a door sort of like a doggie door you got to crawl through. And it's an impossibility for Republicans who are diametrically opposed to Democrats.

So, you know, and this is Chuck, I'd walk a mile for a camera Schumer who is, you know, doing his thing. And it's a bit of a charade.

CASONE: Well, Neil, I mean let's talk about the reality of this, because what Senator Schumer says, is we're going to -- we're willing to come to the table, willing to talk to you. But what can he offer that's not going to get rejected by the Republicans because even the Republicans came up with a plan to replace Obamacare. That the CBO said was more expensive than what the House had proposed.

SROKA: Yes. Well, it's a good question, what can the Republicans meet at Democrats in the middle of the table. The fact of the matter is the way that we actually fixed many of the problems that do exist with Obamacare is by the very least providing a public option if not moving to Medicare for all program overall which is actually the way that we're going to cut the cost curve and bend that cost curve in health insurance. And that provide health insurance for millions of Americans.

In lieu of that, let's actually have real negotiation in an open discussion. If Republicans want to meet Democrats somewhere in the middle, there is certain way to do that and that's called the public option.

CASONE: Ashley, do you think after what we've seen play out in the last hour in particular with the failure of McConnell to get the votes that the Republican leaders are not going to realize that they do need to work in a bipartisan way with Democrats? Do you think that's possible?

HAYEK: Let's see really clear. The Democrats don't want a bipartisan effort. They've never wanted to buy bipartisan effort to try and work with this President. It's only criticisms critiques. The hypocrisy that we've seen from the left is absolutely unreal. Premiums are going to continue to go up under Obamacare. People who are being, "forced out" of the health care by not repealing Obamacare and people who are forced into a health care plan that didn't work for their families.

So, what you're going to see is more people are going to hurt and unfortunately because we weren't able to repeal the health care, Obamacare, and we aren't able to help with anything right now, it's going to continue to just hurt the American people.

CASONE: David, what I'm concerned about right now is it's from the investment side of this.

NELSON: Sure.

CASONE: I mean, these insurance companies, I mean, yes, like, I can do some UnitedHealthcare today, great on the earnings. They're not to be exchanging.

NELSON: But they got a plan. Yes exactly.

CASONE: They're not in Obamacare. So, take them out of the problem. You got Aetna, Humana, these are companies that are -- they've clearly said we can't afford to stay. But we have nothing to fix it.

NELSON: When you look line-item by line-item, you can see why companies like UnitedHealthcare, they are not in the business of losing money. And Neil said it. I mean, look at what this is all about in the first place. It opened up a Pandora's box, the Affordable Care Act. They always wanted a single payer plan, that's where they're trying to go.

CASONE: Do you think we're going single payer?

SROKA: At Medicare for all programs is exactly what corporate America wants. If you actually look over in Canada, corporations love their Medicare program that provides insurance at a much lower cost for everyone else.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: Neil, Neil, I disagree with that. There are many -- we many CEO's that come on to Fox Business and they want healthy employees and not necessarily a single payer system actually.

HAYEH: Exactly.

CASONE: Do you disagree with that. And I can totally disagree with that.

Patrice, Patrice I do want to bring you in. I'm sorry Patrice. But, you know, come on in Patrice, I want to ask you about that because the single- payer system, we keep talking about that possibility. Is that now though a reality?

ONWUKA: I mean it seems increasingly like we might be moving in that direction. But I hope we don't because when we look at Obamacare and the expansion of Medicaid, we have people who have insurance cards but it's putting pressure on a system by overloading the system.

And unfortunately the people who actually need -- the most vulnerable people who need help are the ones who are not able to see the doctors in a timely manner. So to Medicare for our single-payer system is not the solution to real quality care for people.

CASONE: OK. OK. Gregg Jarrett I got about10 seconds, your final thoughts.

JARRETT: There's one other possibility. Repeal Obamacare and then give all of the money earmarked for Medicaid to the states to devise their own plans state by state. I talked to a veteran on Capitol Hill --

CASONE: Yes.

JARRETT: -- over the weekend who said that is actually gaining some strength, it's a real possibility.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: And all of you, thank you so much. We are going to take a quick break, a lot of breaking news on the show. We're going to take a quick commercial break. Stay with us, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Well, turmoil over health care expected to only create more gridlock in Washington. And that is something that J.P. Morgan, CEO Jamie Dimon is fed up with. And he is blaming the media telling reporters, "Why you guys don't write about it every day is completely beyond me." So, is he right? Well, let's bring in Howard Kurtz, Host of Media Buzz. Howard, you have written about his comment, great article by the way. But --

HOWARD KURTZ, MEDIA BUZZ HOST: Thank you.

CASONE: -- is he right?

KURTZ: Well, most Americans would say he's right. Why can't we do something about the partisan paralysis in Washington? The reason it's not written and talked about more is that it's been going on for 20 years, Bush administration, Obama administration, Trump administration. It's like saying that Washington is a real human place in July.

And when you have all this polarization, more polarized parties, more polarized members, more polarized districts, constituents, more polarized media and social media now and you added to a subject that is difficult and treaties as health care, the result is what we have today, nothing gets done.

CASONE: Well, here is the thing. You've got so many story lines going on right now. A lot great in chaos, I'm thinking Donald Trump, Jr. for instance about a meeting that happened a year ago that's, you know, now we're talking hearings and appearances and thing. I mean, does Jamie Dimon have a point that the media needs to refocus on the actual policy debate in Washington? Which is what they voted on last year, which is tax reform that is health care, and get away from the noise?

KURTZ: He has an absolute point. We are so addicted to scandal which is not to say that some of these stories aren't legitimate and shouldn't be covered. But the -- a media oxygen consumed by the side shows, the silly stuff, you know, good at handshake with the First Lady of France really crowds out a lot of the more serious look at taxes infrastructure, things that Americans really care about. I think we are all guilty to some degree about that on that point. The others getting more ratings and clicks but it can be frustrating. I think a lot of people are kind of tuning us out for that very reason.

CASONE: It, you know, it's interesting as, you know, a journalist my self and someone that's worked in different places, I mean, you have to kind of wonder though, if some of our colleagues are making grave mistakes here by focusing on what is a sexy story, and focusing on something that is salacious but doesn't help the country. Doesn't that feed into what Dimon is saying that reporters are getting it wrong?

KURTZ: I think that is true. I also think that some news outlets are tend to be more serious and some sort of don't necessarily put up the big numbers. You know the words there is an audience for this other stuff.

And I think sometimes this President who is obviously fighting on the issues creates so many of the distractions. He goes after, you know, Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski, we all go crazy for three days. So, when you put all those things in the pot, it's very frustrating for me as a lifelong journalist that we don't have more laser focus on the stuff that really touches people's lives as opposed to the gridlock and the bread and circuses aspects. I guess you would say in Washington.

CASONE: Well, that's the thing. If you copies other networks that are -- and I'm not going to call them up by name, but that are covering again, you know, just making basically a 24/7 affair out of attacking President Trump and his daughter and both sons and his grand kids, isn't he? These are people that have to take responsibility for the fact that they're also derailing what matters which is the American life, which is American -- the people that are here.

KURTZ: I think they do have to take some responsibility. The dirty little secret in cable news is you don't need a big mass audience if you can get a million dedicated people to watch them, that's good for your business, not necessarily good for the country.

CASONE: Howard Kurtz, Media Buzz, every Sunday, 11:00 a.m. Eastern time on Fox News. Howard, thank you. And we will be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CASONE: Today, we have learned that the Senate Republican plan to repeal and replace Obamacare just didn't have the votes. And then later Senator McConnell's plan for a vote for a straight repeal also didn't have the votes. Where are we going to go from here? We're going to go Liz Claman right now. Liz over to you.

END
