Antony Funnell: All history is a distortion, of course. It's full of the intended and unintended biases of those who write it. The same is true of our forecasts, our future projections. They say as much about our fears and hopes today as they say about what we really think lies ahead.

There's a lot of concern expressed about the rise of China and what its increasing strength might mean for the West. But framing every discussion in that way, through the prism of rivalry, risks losing sight of the significance of China's development.

As we'll soon hear, in some areas, China is arguably more forward looking and progressive than we might imagine.

Hello, Antony Funnell here. Welcome to the first in our 2018 series of podcasts and programs.

Today on the show, we take a look at three sectors in which China is likely to have massive influence over the next decade or more; in energy, trade and artificial intelligence. In Beijing-speak, let's call them the Three Great Potentials.

We'll begin with trade, and the much vaunted, and oddly named Belt and Road initiative. Here's Nick Bisley, Professor of International Relations at La Trobe University. So, what is the Belt and Road initiative?

Nick Bisley: The simple answer is that it's a vast infrastructure and connectivity program in which China is seeking to significantly enhance the capacity for China to access markets, both in terms of energy, goods, commodities, pretty much everything you can think of, between itself and all points West. It's focused both on over-land connectivity, so building pipelines, highways, bridges, tunnels, roads, rail infrastructure, the whole package, as well as connectivity overseas, so building ports and terminals and the like.

The basic idea that China has is that the links between itself and the West, particularly Europe, the Middle East and Africa, especially over land, are badly overdeveloped, and that it needs, for its own economic development purposes and also for the region as a whole, it needs that connectivity to be significantly enhanced and certainly by all measures you see figures thrown around that are eye-watering in their scale, that Asia as a whole (and that's that broader Eurasian concept of Asia) needs between $9- and $15 trillion worth of infrastructure and investment to get things to where they need to be over the next 20 or 30 years.

So China is seeing itself as being, and it rightly is, the only country that can provide the sort of capacity and skill and of course experience...you know, this is a country that has got good experience at building this kind of stuff. But what China has done so far in terms of its economic development has been focused very much on its eastern seaboard. And so where it sees an external need for infrastructure, it also sees it in its western peripheries, it sees an opportunity to provide a kind of Keynesian economic development program that will have benefits both to itself and improving the prosperity of its western peripheries and western provinces, as well as building that connectivity to the outside world. There's a whole bunch of strategic ambitions that come from that, but that's the basic story. It's an infrastructure story, it's the biggest infrastructure story in the world, quite possibly the biggest infrastructure story the world will have ever seen by the time it's done.

Antony Funnell: So it's potentially massive but it's also still a work in progress, isn't it, even though it was initially launched in 2013.

Nick Bisley: Yes, so it began with these two speeches, one in Kazakhstan and one in Indonesia in 2013 in which Xi Jinping laid out a vision for maritime connectivity and then over-land connectivity, the over land being in Kazakhstan and sea in Indonesia. But at that stage it was really just a couple of speeches and everyone looked and thought what does this mean. And over time they've built up this program which remains still pretty general in the sense that it's not got a clear charter and 55 different programs yet affiliated with it, but it's essentially a statement that says China wants to provide this infrastructure and connectivity, it's open pretty much to anyone who wants to join. And at the 19th party Congress which was held in November 2017, it has become the signature international policy initiative and is being written into the party constitution. So it says this is a priority, number one priority of the party and number one priority of Xi Jinping, but also if you want to get anything done in terms of infrastructure development within China, you have to put it in terms of the Belt and Road initiative. So it's sort of about signalling domestic priorities as well.

Antony Funnell: And 68 countries, as I understand it, has now signalled that they want to be part of this initiative in some way or form. But unlike one of the Beijing's other major international initiatives, the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, this Belt and Road initiative is not constituted yet, is it, as a multilateral project, it's very much being led by Beijing.

Nick Bisley: It's absolutely a Beijing-led initiative. The 68 countries that have signed up to date have signed memorandums of understanding which are essentially pretty general, saying we are committed to this, but nothing in specific terms. There's a couple of big projects that are in train already. The China-Pakistan economic corridor is a pretty large program that is already fairly far down the path. But there is not an 'it' in some respects, there isn't a headquarters, there isn't a set of institutions, there isn't a set of principles or agreements or a charter yet. I wouldn't be surprised if over time you end up with a World Bank type central fund that is managing all of these sorts of projects that has got principles around it about how loans and the like to do with the infrastructure investment are managed, but as yet it's not there and it's because it's still pretty much in its infancy.

Antony Funnell: Now, of course, as with almost everything to do with China's development these days there are suspicions about this project and where it will head, aren't there.

Nick Bisley: So if you are suspicious of China, so if you see in everything that China does threats, risk and vulnerabilities, then boy, this is worrying because it is so vast, and because what it is trying to do potentially involves countries all around its borders but also pretty far-flung countries, from Europe, Africa and even Latin America being tied economically into China's orbit and increasingly having their country's economic interests aligned with Beijing's. From a geopolitical point of view that's just a worrisome thing, if you are someone who thinks that China is a threat and a risk.

But there is also ambitions that China has to I think not only, as I said earlier, develop its western peripheries, it also wants through this program to develop countries in its border land. So it wants Pakistan not just to be a thoroughfare through which hydrocarbons can come from the Arabian Sea to Xinjiang, or Chinese goods travel out to market. More importantly, what it wants out of this program is a Pakistan that's more economically developed, and it wants that...and that's true in Kazakhstan and elsewhere, and it wants that because it wants these countries to be more stable, a fairly classic liberal idea in some respects that an economically developed country is one that is less susceptible to terrorism, it's less susceptible to extremism. And it's also likely (and Pakistani is a big country) to be a market that can consume Chinese manufactured goods, particularly if, as China wants, it moves up the technological sophistication scale and becomes a country that is exporting not just cheap white goods or clothes but is producing its own cars and mid and high-tech kit. So it's very much in its interests to have it as a kind of infrastructure development program. And so it's got these multiple layers to it.

The problem is...not the problem but the challenge is if you look at this thing and ago I think there's economic opportunity in it, whether you are an infrastructure company or whether you are the Pakistani government, that's true, but if you also see this as a geopolitical risk, that is also a perfectly reasonable conclusion to reach, because one of China's big ambitions from a geopolitical point of view with this program is to reduce its vulnerability to maritime predation. The moment China's economic development and growth depends on its inputs and outputs being able to travel without any challenge to its eastern seaboards, what that means is at the moment China is vulnerable, if the US Seventh Fleet wants to, to basically choke off its economic growth. Now, why it would want to do that given the interdependence between the US and China is a separate issue, but that vulnerability is real. What it is seeking to do in building this infrastructure out to its west is to reduce that vulnerability. Not to get rid of it altogether. It knows that it is never going to be able to reduce that to zero. But if you can get your energy supplier, whether it's oil or gas, if you can get a fair chunk of the commodity inflows from Africa and you can get a fair amount of the commodity outflows to western Europe and the Middle East without having to go through the eastern seaboard, then you strengthen your position in relation to the US. So there is a big geopolitical gain there, and if you are in Canberra or Tokyo or Washington, if this comes off (and it's a big if) then China's relative position in the region is going to be increased and consequently Washington's will be decreased. So there's potentially a transformative geopolitical consequence of this initiative.

Antony Funnell: And what about China's capacity to actually see this through? Because there are those who doubt that China really does have the economic might to guarantee at least the sort of loans that would be involved in this type of development.

Nick Bisley: Yes, there's two issues here that worry people, not so much from that strategic point of view but from a practical economic point of view which is this is a top-down initiative, which is saying to Chinese banks who've got a lot of capital sitting around on their balance sheets and trying to figure out what to do with it, to say thou shalt go and invest in infrastructure projects. And of course the issue with infrastructure projects is they are high risk, low yield propositions, which is the reverse of what you want. And a lot of people think what you're going to see is some pretty serious misallocation of capital in China, where best case scenario is you've got banks and others putting money into what are effectively white elephants in which the return on capital is poor and that money would be much better spent invested in other things, so building at vast expense hydrocarbon pipelines over geologically unstable, extraordinarily challenging terrain in Kazakhstan or in Pakistan. The engineering of this stuff is astonishing. They are at 6,000 and 7,000 metres above sea level. So that's one problem.

The other problem is to do with the potential economic millstone around the neck of the recipient countries, where China, because it can dictate terms, may well succumb to the temptation to put punitive loan conditions on this sort of stuff, in which countries then, not dissimilar to the loan crises of the 1980s where Latin American countries and others found themselves in a very bad situation because of punitive interest rates with infrastructure loans that they can't possibly pay off. So you could see across China's periphery not only misallocation of capital leading to bad use of resources, but all these countries being economically much worse off than they would otherwise be because they are chained to these white elephant investments that seem like a good idea and that they can't possibly pay off. And the consequence of that we know economically in Latin America was 10 to 15 years of really bad economic growth. So just because China has got this big grand plan and it has pulled it off in the past, I think the jury is still out on whether it will be able to deliver what it wants on this project because it's so damn big.

Antony Funnell: And that was Nick Bisley, Professor of International Relations at La Trobe University.

Moving on now to artificial intelligence and to Will Knight, the senior editor for AI at the MIT Technology Review.

Will Knight: There is an incredible boom going on in China. There's a huge economic boom that has been going on for a while, and there are lots of companies and industries that are booming, and the technology industry there is at the forefront of that. At the same time the academic world in China is really coming on leaps and bounds. Most recently there was a very big commitment by the Chinese government to put a huge sum, like a staggering amount of money, like tens of billions of dollars into AI, and there's a real desire to see that industry, which has been identified as one of the most important ones, rightly so I think, really boom more and more.

And the rate at which things develop are pretty extraordinary. I have been travelling to China for the last couple of years, and I think that the picture has changed even in that amount of time, and it's only...compared to, say, a decade ago it's really amazing how many AI start-ups there are and how many start-ups that are doing really cutting-edge work...you know, there are a lot of companies out there that people haven't heard of outside of China that are producing some research which is really cutting-edge, which is really up there, matching the likes of Google and Facebook and Microsoft in certain areas.

Antony Funnell: There is a tendency to look at China and to see it as a country that follows the trends that others set, but from what you're saying there with AI, that is happening but China is also innovating.

Will Knight: Absolutely, yes. I think it's worth recognising that in the past few years in the technology scene some companies have started to lead, and there are definitely cases where technology companies in the West are now copying Chinese companies, and that's not to say that...I think the likes of Google and Facebook, they are leading the way in terms of absolutely cutting-edge research, but in some areas Chinese companies are going their own way, and partly it's because they have this unique market, it's very mobile first, they have an enormous number of people, the way people buy stuff is kind of different. So you have these new opportunities where companies are really carving out their own niche, being much more original.

But yes, I think you're absolutely right, maybe 10, 15 years ago it was purely a case of copycat, or even five years ago, companies just literally copying the business model, maybe innovating a little bit, and that has definitely changed. I think what I've also discovered from visiting these companies is there's a real appetite to change that even more, and AI is seen as one of the ways to do that. You know, if you want to be innovative, if you want to genuinely I guess be one of the biggest companies there is, you have to do your own thing, and AI is right at the forefront of being original in technology and in technological research.

Antony Funnell: And the sheer amount of data that is available in China...I mean, China has a massive population, it has a massive usage of social media technology, of the internet in general, that has to be a plus I would imagine for the Chinese in developing AI.

Will Knight: Yes, it's not just a plus, it's arguably a really huge advantage or even a game changer because today's AI algorithms are very much data fed, they really depend on your data. And if you have much more data, maybe a few times more data in some cases, you potentially can develop much better algorithms. And I have seen people argue that that access to data is really a huge allure for researchers. And it's true that people want to get their hands on the biggest dataset they can possibly get because then you can do extraordinary new things with it. So the ability to do amazingly accurate face recognition and voice recognition depended on having enough examples. So having all these examples of other kinds of data may prove really important, for sure.

Antony Funnell: Many of the AI experts, as I understand it, who are working in China, have a background with the US tech giants. And as you just alluded to there, there are Chinese organisations like Sinovation Ventures that are actively recruiting now in the US, aren't they.

Will Knight: Yes, and it's become...this kind of fight for talent which is already incredibly fierce in the US but AI talent has become international, and the biggest players are really the companies from in China and the US. And it's starting to shift, you get more and more Chinese companies coming and setting up operations. Like Baidu and Tencent have research labs, at least one in Silicon Valley and in some cases more than one where they are trying to tap into the talent there. And increasingly people are trying to lure researchers back to China. I remember visiting SenseTime, which is a start-up in the China, as some of the researchers there had been working for Microsoft in the US and said, you know, I actually came back because it just seemed like the opportunity was so huge. One thing was the data. And it was just the business moves so quickly there, the ideas that you can see get off the ground very quickly, there's an excitement around it. And you can see that there is a pull for a lot of people to return perhaps.

Antony Funnell: You believe that it's not correct to view this development simply in terms of competition with the West, which is the sort of narrative that often comes up when talking about China and its development. What sort of potential do you see for the AI push in China to have a positive influence in the rest of the world?

Will Knight: That's a great question. I mean, it's much too simplistic to look at it purely in terms of rivalry and competition. Obviously there is competition for example in the case of trying to get talent, but it's also the case that as with a lot of big technological shifts, it's not necessarily a zero sum game. So if China reboots its entire energy industry with AI, it doesn't mean that the US can't do that. And so just as the research coming out of the US has had a big impact on general knowledge and application of AI around the world, it's quite possible, certainly at the moment, because Chinese researchers are publishing their work, that it could have a similar effect in moving the technology forward.

There certainly is a lot of competition between these big tech companies, but in some ways that can be good for the new technologies that emerge out of it, and that's one thing that I certainly think is a legitimate hope for what will happen.

Antony Funnell: As you mentioned, the Chinese government has promised significant investment in AI technology. They do have a lot on their plate, they've got a lot of priority, and the country itself has a lot of pressing problems to deal with. Is there a sense that they will have the capacity to follow through on their big AI vision?

Will Knight: There is that sense, for sure, because they tend to follow through when they make really big pronouncements. There have been other examples, like when they wanted to build a big high speed rail network they absolutely made that happen. When they promised to put money into the chip industry there they really have put a lot of that capital in and they are yet to see the results of that but they certainly backed it up. And I think that the idea is that AI just has so much potential to transform a lot of industries, and that is exactly the sort of thing that the Chinese government I believe would look at or any government should look at and say that's really critical to invest in. So my sense is that...and certainly based on this big plan, that they have identified it as a very important priority. And one thing is it can help increase the productivity of your economy, which is very important, and something that every country needs to really think of. So they have a lot of stuff on their plate, but I think that this is maybe one key way to manage the transitions that are ahead.

Antony Funnell: Will Knight, senior editor for AI at the MIT Technology Review, thank you very much for joining us.

Will Knight: Thank you for having me.

Tim Buckley: China is absolutely dominating the global landscape for energy market transformation, and late last year the IEA put out their World Energy Outlook 2017 and they openly acknowledged as an upfront conclusion; China is changing and that changes everything.

Antony Funnell: Tim Buckley is the director of Energy Finance Studies Australasia at the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis.

Tim Buckley: China in 2017 absolutely dominated the energy market transformation trends. And maybe to throw a couple of numbers out, I think China is likely to have represented 36% of world wind turbine installations, they would have represented possibly 40% of world hydro installations, and 50% or nearly 50% of all solar installs globally in 2017. Those are staggering numbers. So China is absolutely leading the world in adopting, embracing and driving trends in new energy.

Antony Funnell: And again, in terms of perspective, is it correct that Chinese global investment in clean energy is twice what the US, the biggest economy in the world, is investing?

Tim Buckley: That's in the right ballpark, correct, and China has been expanding very aggressively. Probably the only reason why that number hasn't been higher is the magnitude of deflation evident in the renewable energy sector means that in 2017 you invest $100, you'd probably get 20% or 30% more bang for your buck than you would have a year or two earlier in terms of installed capacity. So you are seeing absolute double-digit deflation in the cost of renewable energy, and that is one of the reasons, one of the many reasons why China is absolutely embracing the move to a low emissions energy profile.

If you had to identify probably the two key drivers, one in almost all circumstances in any country is energy security as a key driver. The second one for China is the environment, and that is a massive change on where we were maybe five years ago were China was growing its economy at 10% annually, it was growing its energy consumption 10% annually and they needed more of absolutely everything.

The change that we saw in 2015, 2016 and again in 2017 was that they've invested aggressively in low emissions technologies such as wind, solar, hydro, energy efficiency, and even nuclear, and that is very much driven by, as the President said in his People's Congress opening speech back three or four months ago, he talked about the critical need to return China to blue skies, and pollution was an absolute imperative on the Chinese leadership.

Antony Funnell: So they dominate in investment in solar, wind and hydroelectric power and nuclear power, as you were saying, they also have the lion's share of investment in the global lithium market, don't they.

Tim Buckley: Absolutely. We've recently released a report titled New Energy Outbound Investment Trends 2018 for China, and we identify that China is looking at the entire supply chain, and so when we talk about that it's not just lithium iron but it's cobalt, it's copper, it is rare earth, it's the actual battery manufacturing, it's electric vehicles, as well as, as you said, wind, hydro, solar and so on. So they are looking to dominate all sorts of aspects of investment. Sorry, I didn't mention the grid is a huge area of investment, it's probably 40% of global investment in the electricity sector annually, and China looks to be the absolute world leader in grid investments as yet another example where they are looking to dominate massive industries of the future, and they are doing it for all sorts of reasons. They're doing it because they now have the best technologies in the world, they are driving investment and financing of those investments globally, they are doing it for employment reasons, they are doing it because it's environmental, they want to be an industry leader for all sorts of reasons as well as, as you mentioned, pollution and so on.

Antony Funnell: And in terms of their international push, leaving aside the domestic needs that they are meeting, where they focusing, what countries?

Tim Buckley: China is somewhat agnostic as to where they go with their investments, particularly in the renewable energy. For the last two or three decades China has dominated inbound investment into Africa, for example, which is a higher risk, more longer term investment program that they've taken. It's coupled with their foreign aid but ultimately it's about securing resources of Africa. But increasingly they are investing in new domestic infrastructure, energy infrastructure across Africa. But they are very focused in their One Belt, One Road initiative in outbound investment in numerous countries. Pakistan over 2017 announced $50 billion of investment intent in Pakistan across wind, coal, import coal facilities, hydro, nuclear, solar, the grid itself, building railways and highways. So Pakistan is probably the single biggest country destination for outbound investment from China, but it is not just neighbours to China, whether it's Bangladesh or Pakistan, it's also Africa, it is Latin America, it's Europe and America and Australia, to the extent that they have regulatory approval to expand in each of those markets. So they are expanding virtually in all markets around the world and cementing their global leadership in technology.

Antony Funnell: Tim Buckley from the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis, thank you very much.

Tim Buckley: Thank you very much for your time.

Antony Funnell: So there we are, the Three Great Potentials for China over the next decade; energy, international trade and artificial intelligence.

Thanks also to Will Knight from the MIT Technology Review, and Professor Nick Bisley the executive director of La Trobe Asia and also a Professor of International Relations at La Trobe University.

Coming up next week on Future Tense, dominance of another kind, the rise in influence of the GIF, the Graphics Interchange Format, in other words those little video loops that more and more people are using in their digital communication.

Unknown: If you look back at the history of writing, there hasn't always been the kind of complete divorce between the written word and the picture that we think of as normal for writing. If you look back at the mediaeval monks, the early illuminated manuscripts with all of this hand written, hand copied manuscripts, they often drew these very ornate drawings around the first letter of a manuscript or around the titles or around in the margins of all the different types of things. There's always been this kind of interplay between pictures and even between letters and the linguistic side, and I think that's something...it's more of a return to the marriage of pictures and writing than it is this wholesale shift to pictures only, which...I don't think we are going to end up at only pictures, we're going to have more of a balance between the two.

Unknown: They are incredibly widely used. They are kind of a lingua franca of the social Web. So GIFs are kind of inescapable. They were resisted for a long time by popular social media platforms, so Twitter and Facebook didn't support GIFs from the start, they only came on board later on. And for news organisations as well, having a GIF that distils a key moment of the story or a key aspect of the story is also useful for readers on their mobile devices, for instance. They don't have to load a two-minute video, they can just see the moment of interest on repeat.

Unknown: I find on Twitter you have a shortened character limit, you only have a small amount of space to say what you have to say, and GIFs can be a really effective way of communicating. So I think it's that idea of a picture says a thousand words.

Antony Funnell: That's the rise of the GIF, next on Future Tense.

Karin Zsivanovits is my co-producer. The sound engineer was Steve Fieldhouse. I'm Antony Funnell. Until next time, cheers!

Mar 17, 2019( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1]. View original post here[2]. Although there are no autonomous vehicles for sale to the public at the moment, the American people remain skeptical of these Silicon Valley cars that are currentlybeing testedacross the country. Take, for example, Elaine Herzberg, shewas walking her bicycle across a Tempe, Arizona street when an autonomous Uber ran her over. The story was widely publicized, along with other incidents.

The latest consumer report shows that recent negative press concerning self-driving vehicles has incited fear among the vast majority of Americans. The American Automobile Association's (AAA) annual automated vehicle survey[3] found that 71% of people are terrified to ride in self-driving vehicles. That's about a 13% increase in fear levels rom April 2018 after the Tempe fatality. Before the incident, fear of self-driving cars was at 63%. The survey revealed that only 19% of respondents said they were comfortable with self-driving cars. AAA believes there is much work to be done to improve consumers' perception of self-driving vehicles. 'Automated vehicle technology is evolving on a very public stage and, as a result, it is affecting how consumers feel about it,' said Greg Brannon, AAA's director of Automotive Engineering and Industry Relations. 'Having the opportunity to interact with partially or fully automated vehicle technology will help remove some of the mystery for consumers and open the door for greater acceptance.' 'Despite fears still running high, AAA's study also shows that Americans are willing to take baby steps toward incorporating this type of technology into their lives,' continued Brannon. 'Hands-on exposure in more controlled, low-risk environments coupled with stronger education will play a key role in easing fears about self-driving cars.' AAA Northern California, Nevada ...ah, in partnership with the city of Las Vegas, Keolis North Americaand the Regional Transportation Commission of Southern Nevada,tested the first and largest self-driving metro bus for public consumption,all to sway public opinion that self-driving vehiclesare safe. The self-driving bus was the first in the country to be used in a city environment. The public had a voluntary opportunity to participate in a survey about their post-ride experience. Of those who responded, many described their overall mood improved towards the self-driving vehicles. Play Video[4] More than half of Americans (55%) believe by the end of the next decade, mostcars willbe outfittedwithautonomousfeatures. Those who are skeptical that autonomous vehicles will be driving on roads in the nearterm,cite reasons such as technology not being fullymatured and government regulation. While experts agree that self-driving vehicles could arrive by the mid-2020s, Silicon Valley and big tech are behind the curve in convincing the American people that this new form of transportation is safe. urn:contentItem:5TDR-0841-F0K1-N22C-00000-00-Three Key Takeaways from SWIFT's Business Forum New York2018-10-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:36ZLexisNexis-Three Key Takeaways from SWIFT's Business Forum New York

From big tech to fintech, here's what you need to know from this year's forum

SWIFT's Business Forum New York 2018 welcomed 700 guests from across the world of banking, technology and beyond, to debate the future of the financial services industry. Representatives from FIs, big tech, fintechs, global news outlets, academics and international organisations, all joined together to debate some of the critical themes facing the industry - How will big tech firms entering financial services impact the market? How can new technologies such as AI, machine learning and quantum computing transform our services? And, how can we use these technologies to deliver intuitive applications that work for us as humans, not machines?



SWIFT Business Forum New York 2018

Below we have pulled-out three key insights to take away from these discussions:

Learn from the big tech - facilitate user platforms ecosystems

Based on the sheer scale of the number of users on the their platforms, companies such as Facebook, Google, Apple and others should be thought of more as countries than tech companies, said Rana Foroohar, Global Business Columnist, The Financial Times and Global Economic Analyst, CNN, in her opening keynote on Re-imagining Financial Services.

Rana Foroohar - Global Business Columnist, The Financial Times and Global Economic Analyst, CNN

These platforms have disrupted and transformed sectors across the globe, and now they are entering financial services, noted Foroohar. They have the power, not only to compete in the market, but become the market, and there is nothing to stop a company like Google or Amazon coming into this space in the US and globally. Tech platform players can sit in the middle of a commerce market and take a percentage of every transaction, similarly to the traditional financial services model, she continued.

FIs need to adopt a whole new world-view in order to thrive in this world, she said, by studying the business model that is challenging them, and identify how they themselves can facilitate user platforms and ecosystems.

Foroohar underlined the power of data in this quest. 'Data is dollars,' she said. The tech firms have grown through a number of reasons - one of which is the power of data. The personal data that we are willing give them is essentially the new oil, she said. Yet, sounding a positive note, she said that banks are sitting on a tremendous amount of data that is not currently being monetised - and when you have the data, you can enhance it into smart data by applying technologies such as machine learning. Now is the time to understand how that can work in the financial sector, said Foroohar, not just to better know your customers' needs, but to understand how to service them in a way that they want.

Trust is fundamental, she stressed. Banks have long protected their customers' data and become their trusted advisor. To compete with the coming challenge from big tech in financial services, she concluded, FIs need to build ecosystems, leverage their data and deliver trust, transparency and value to their customers.

Seize the opportunities new technologies can offer - now!

It was clear from discussions throughout the day that we now sit on the cusp of a technological wave that will transform financial services as we know them today. As such, there was a general consensus that FIs should already be embracing new technologies - from quantum computing to AI, machine learning, cloud edge computing and beyond - to ensure they are the first to offer their users the financial services of the future.

The session, Technology Enabling Digital Transformation, brought together a multi-disciplinary panel of speakers from big tech, fintech and banking to discuss how their organisations are already deploying these technologies and what the financial industry can learn from their experiences.

Asked how AI could change the landscape, Mike Blalock, General Manager, Financial Services Industry Vertical at Intel said it will usher in a much better world, solving real-world problems in a fraction of the time. Financial services is a data business, he said, and we are going from a person-based ecosystem to a machine-based ecosystem, which massively ramps up the amount of data being generated. We are in the early stages of AI, Blalock said, and are only leveraging 1% of the data we possess, so there is a huge opportunity to grow this.

Saket Sharma , Chief Information Officer, Treasury Services Technology, BNY Mellon, agreed that AI is still in its infancy. Noting the current move from predictive to prescriptive data analytics, he said we still don't know what it will mean from a risk perspective when machines make assumptions on a prescriptive model.

Amar Parikh, Customer Engineer at Google Cloud said that financial services companies generate so much data, and if they have the ability to add real-time analytics and machine learning to this they could benefit and create new revenue streams. Yet Parikh noted that with the high regulatory and compliance requirements in financial services, a business like Google Cloud needs the capabilities to respond to this. Security is also vital at every layer, he said, and customers need to understand how they can use the tools available to have the best controls possible.

Blalock concluded by summoning the theme of the forum, saying that FIs need to 'seize the opportunity' of new technologies right away. A lot of banks have AI projects, he said, but they need to move faster to have an institution-wide view of AI in order to take the opportunity that now exists, before third-parties beat them to the punch.

Never forget your users are humans, not machines

While the potential for deploying new technologies in financial services was a key theme of the forum, Amber Case, Cyborg Anthropologist Harvard Fellow, reminded us in the closing plenary that, whatever the technology deployed, applications must be designed for humans, not machines.

Amber Case - Cyborg Anthropologist Harvard Fellow

The core of Case' argument was the need for 'calm technology' - technology that sits in the background, requiring the least possible amount of attention to solve a problem, and thus becoming a part of the user's life rather than a distraction from it. Technology should amplify the best of humanity by blending tech seamlessly with our everyday lives, she said.

It is possible to have 'too much tech', she said. For example, 'smart' watches that notify you to the exactly same information as your phone, or 'smart' fridges that ping you with unnecessary alerts about the condition of your vegetables. Humans need applications that are fun to look at and intuitive, she said, only alerting you to the things you care about, by learning about your individual needs.

More devices, features and functionalities are not necessarily the answer, she said. We should design products that work well, launch well, are easy to support, easy to use, and remain unobtrusive, she said. When applying this sentiment to B2B, FIs should deliver 'calm financial services' with low impact, light footprint that require as little time, energy and cost as possible for end-customers to run and maintain.

For additional coverage of the event, visit the Finextra live blog, or the wrap up article.

urn:contentItem:60J0-9H51-JBCM-F1XV-00000-00Three Major Issues Coming Up That Could Make Or Break The 2020 Stock Market2020-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:36ZLexisNexisThree Major Issues Coming Up That Could Make Or Break The 2020 Stock MarketSergei KlebnikovForbes Staff

Here are some catalysts investors should watch for until the end of the year.

TOPLINE

Second quarter corporate earnings are turning out much better than expected, and now investors are refocusing their attention towards fiscal stimulus plans, vaccine data, and the U.S. election, which could make or break the stock market s run going into the end of 2020.

<figure class="embed-base image-embed embed-4">

<figcaption>

Here are some major catalysts investors should watch for until the end of the year.

John Nacion/STAR MAX/IPx

</figcaption> </figure>

KEY FACTS

So far, 424 companies in the S&P 500 have reported second quarter earnings with 82% beating Wall Street expectations the highest rate on record dating back to 1994, according to Refinitiv data. 

As earnings season winds down, investors are now closely watching for more updates on the next round of coronavirus stimulus from Congress, which remains deadlocked over key provisions like extending federal unemployment benefits.

While both Democratic and Republican leaders have expressed optimism that an agreement will eventually be reached, various market experts havewarnedthat if the next bill continues to be delayed that could result in a market sell-off.

The other outstanding issue for markets is the November 2020presidential election: Although Joe Biden surged in the polls since March, his lead has diminished somewhat in the last several weeks as the number of national coronavirus cases declines.

The country seems too polarized for a landslide election and investors should look for polls to tighten in the coming weeks and months, says Vital Knowledge founder Adam Crisafulli, adding that there are also rising market fears about disputed election results given the large number of mail-in ballots this year.

The [presidential] debates this year will be crucial and the country will be watching these events very closely given the lack of traditional campaigning amid the pandemic, he says, which could lead to further volatility in the polls.

A potential upside for the market could come from more positive vaccine data, which could arrive as early as this fall, however: Several companies are leading the way in finding a treatment for coronavirus, including Moderna, Pfizer and Novavax.

Key background

While the consensus among many investors is that stocks will decline if Biden defeats Trump for the presidency, someexperts disagree: I think people will view it as the storm being over and that will help restore confidence in the markets, says Lewis Altfest, chief investment officer of Altfest Personal Wealth Management. Though Wall Street remains apprehensive about a tax hike under Biden who has pledged to rollback Trump s corporate tax cuts and business deregulation we re past that, we have too much debt and we re going to have to raise taxes regardless in order to pay for all of the coronavirus stimulus, Altfest says.

What to watch for

Rising U.S.-China tensions, which some experts have dubbed a new Cold War. Diplomatic relations between the world s two largest economies have continued to deteriorate, with disputes over a range of matters including trade, Hong Kong, Huawei, Taiwan, the South China Sea and several human rights issues. The latest disagreement stems from Chinese technology companies like TikTok, which the U.S. claims is collecting data on Americans for the Chinese government. After initiallythreatening to banthe social media app, President Trump said earlier this week that he would give tech giant Microsoft the go-ahead to pursue an acquisition if a very substantial portion of the proceeds go to the U.S. Treasury. That sparked outrage in China, with several state-run media outlets calling it an open robbery of a Chinese tech company. Alongside the other fronts of U.S.-China tensions, the growing tech confrontation further troubles the viability of the phase one trade deal, Evan Rees, Asia Pacific Analyst with Stratfor, a RANE company, recently toldForbes.

Tangent

Big Tech companies, which are among the best-performing stocks so far this year, also continue to be in the regulatory crosshairs of Washington. Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Google have all been reported to be the subject of various antitrust probes, with their respective CEOs testifying before Congress last month. Investors just aren t concerned at all after years of fruitless actions and empty threats, argues Crisafulli. This boy has cried wolf way too many times for markets to be concerned.

urn:contentItem:5XFB-7M41-DYRW-V0M8-00000-00Three New Developments from the World of Data and Insight2019-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:36ZLexisNexisEXECUTIVE INSIGHTSDATA AND INSIGHTPg. 34Three New Developments from the World of Data and InsightFINN RABEN

finn@esomar.org, FINN RABEN is director general of ESOMAR. He has spent most of his career in market research, previously working at Millward Brown IMS in Dublin, Nielsen, TNS and Synovate. Raben serves as an external examiner at the International School of Management in Avans University in the Netherlands.

The data and insights industry is constantly evolving, whether through fast-changing technology, understanding of consumer psychology or the impact of legislation. With so much going on, marketers can struggle to keep track of developments that are likely to impact their work. So what do marketers need to know?

1 Sampling Becomes Programmatic

The data and insights industry is part innovator and part magpie, constantly adopting technology to transform data collection and analysis.

One example is programmatic, which has revolutionized the way digital advertising is bought and sold, as well as changed the buying and selling of research samples.

Traditionally, a market research agency or brand would go to a panel provider to buy samples for interviews. This sample might come from the provider's propriety panel, but often it would be made up of a mixture of samples from numerous providers, with a variable mix of quality standards. However, taking inspiration from the marketing industry, some companies are providing programmatic samples using automated technologies and filters. This allows the buyer to work with one platform to access multiple suppliers, improving speed, consistency and transparency at a lower cost.

This doesn't mean that traditional panel providers are obsolete. Programmatic is ideal for tactical projects that require quick turnaround. But the expertise of a recognized panel provider is necessary for in-depth projects or niche, hard-to-reach or B2B audiences where a proprietary managed panel is more appropriate.

2 Poor Data Practices and Consumer Trust

It has recently come to light that Facebook paid human contractors to transcribe customers' Facebook Messenger calls. This may not be surprising; there have been plenty of conspiracy theories about Facebook listening to calls and adjusting advertising to fit. Alas, those theories are now based on fact. Add the $5 billion fine the Federal Trade Commission imposed on the company earlier in the year and you'd be forgiven for thinking that Facebook's days are numbered. So why did Facebook stock improve the day after news broke of the largest-ever FTC fine?

Facebook profits were $5 billion in the first three months of 2018 alone, so the FTC fine was a weak slap on the wrist, showing investors that even the worst behavior will not affect company revenues too badly. Even if the data may have been acquired in an underhand way, it nevertheless made the company enormously data-rich.

Increasing data privacy in the U.S. may come back to bite Facebook in the derriere. A joint study from ESOMAR, HERE Technologies, BuzzBack and Cint that was carried out this summer shows that trust in Facebook is particularly low compared to its Big Tech peers. We explored attitudes toward data collection practices across 12 countries and 12,000 people. Our results show that 62% of Americans don't trust Facebook with their personal data. That may still seem low, but when you compare it to Google (31%), Apple (32%) and Amazon (20%), the negative impact of Facebook's actions is clear.

The study found that 71% of people would be more likely to share personal data if they understood how it's used. More than 40% of U.S. consumers are more likely to buy a product or service from a company that they know handles personal data responsibly.

There is a tendency for brands-particularly those in tech or who collect data from mobile applications-to do it surreptitiously. Personal data is often collected without companies being transparent with the data subject. There's a fear that if consumers have a choice, then they won't provide their data. But our new research tells a different story: Be open, honest and transparent and not only will people share, but you'll start to rebuild trust.

3 Impact of the EU Copyright Directive

For those international marketers who work in or around the EU, or the eagle-eyed individuals who keep track of EU legislation as a harbinger of what might come to the U.S., you may have encountered the EU copyright directive.

After the General Data Protection Regulation, the copyright directive has been the most significant development in recent months. It generated vast speculation about memes being banned. This was primarily due to Draft Article 13, which was designed to protect artists and content creators. This article was and remains strongly opposed by companies such as Google and YouTube and by some content creators, as it would potentially limit the freedom of the internet. But a casual glance at Twitter suggests it has done little to affect the social currency of memes.

There's more to the directive than Article 13. It also does much to improve the bargaining position of authors and performers, and is positive for traditional media publishers such as newspapers and non-aggregated commercial content platforms. This is because they've always had to prove or validate sources when reporting a story or publicizing a campaign. Digital media (to date) has not had to do so. Many would consider this a prime reason for the rise of fake news and unregulated personal targeting. If you're considering running marketing or creative campaigns in Europe, be aware that digital platforms are now obligated to meet the same standards as traditional ones when it comes to licensed materials and ethical boundaries.

From the data side comes further positive news. Prior to the drafting of the legislation, my own organization, ESOMAR, formed a coalition with several other associations to ensure any new copyright frameworks did not affect the area of text and digital data mining. Although the framework was initially only intended to benefit academic research, a broader exemption has now been achieved that enables any market or social researcher the right to mine text and data. This exemption can be summarized as "the right to read is the right to mine," meaning that if you have lawful access to the data, you have the right to mine it without having to obtain further permission or licenses.

Given the vast amount of text-based data now available, the EU has taken the opportunity to open this up for research. The ability to mine text data is crucial for artificial intelligence, where huge amounts of real-world, text-based data are needed to train the algorithms. Without this exemption, machine-learning projects would have only been sustainable by cash-rich organizations. Now it's available to all, and we've managed to defend a key source of consumer insight.

In an increasingly global world, the impact of new technologies is felt everywhere. Whether using programmatic to simplify research sample buying, maintain consumer trust in brands or simply protect creatives, the contract of the marketer with the consumer must be one of mutual honesty and transparency. Brands are increasingly realizing that it's important to make sales and behave ethically while doing so. Those that build honest connections will benefit in the long-run.

urn:contentItem:60S0-19V1-JCJY-G2MK-00000-00Three reasons why this tech sell-off is not Dotcom 2.0;Big Tech's remarkable rally has stalled but their robust balance sheets and sizable profits will ensure there is no repeat from 20 years ago2020-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:36ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYVersion:3Three reasons why this tech sell-off is not Dotcom 2.0Big Tech's remarkable rally has stalled but their robust balance sheets and sizable profits will ensure there is no repeat from 20 years agoBy Michael Cogley, Technology Correspondent

Big Tech's remarkable rally has stalled but their robust balance sheets and sizable profits will ensure there is no repeat from 20 years ago

The unrelenting rise of the world's biggest tech stocks came to an abrupt halt on Wednesday.

Finally, vindication for bears swearing the run on Silicon Valley's top names was nothing more than a repeat of the dot com bubble that shook the industry 20 years ago.

Big Tech has spent the year dragging the value of the Nasdaq upwards, but this week it lead the first "bad day" on Wall Street since June.

Elon Musk's Tesla, which had to split its shares last month because they had become so expensive, saw its share price plummet by as much as 15pc since Wednesday morning. Cupertino giant Apple was also hit, slipping 12.4pc, less than two weeks after chief executive Tim Cook sold $131.7m worth of stock in the company.

Google and Facebook dropped 5pc and 2.6pc respectively while Amazon-the white knight of lockdown-fell by 6.4pc. Early US trading on Friday also pointed to continued sell-offs with many of the world's biggest tech firms nursing sizeable knocks to their valuations.

The downward trend continued as The Financial Times reported on Friday that SoftBank was the "Nasdaq whale" that has driven high levels of price inflation among tech stocks. It is believed the Japanese investment giant has poured billions of dollars into tech options that may have led much of the rally in prices in recent months. When pressed on the claims SoftBank said it had no comment on the matter.

But in a year that has seen many investors made considerably more wealthy thanks to their bets on tech, the ongoing sell off looks more like profit taking than a throwback to the crash that wiped out 78pc of the value of the Nasdaq. Here are three reasons why:

Tech's outperformance of the market is nowhere near as outlandish as in 1999

Throughout the 1990s investors to its name, insisting that the internet was the future. To one extent, they were right.

But the outperformance of tech in 1999 is still multiples of what has been reported this year, despite strong growth from tech stocks.

The tech sector's price to earnings (PE) ratio-which is a measure of how much a company earns compared to its share price-is high this year. Currently it's around 90pc greater the average of the rest of the market, according to figures from Capital Economics.

While that may raise some eyebrows it still remains far below the dreaded run up to 2000. Back then the PE ratio was almost 250pc that of the rest of the market. Below is the overall share price performance of tech stocks against the rest of the S&P 500. While they are outperforming the market, they have not bubbled up in the same manner as 2000.

"Big tech's valuation has risen steadily for a few years and it's quite big now, but it's clearly not in the same league as the IT sector when the dot com mania was in full swing," says Oliver Jones, an economist at Capital Economics. "This is one reason why we remain wary of the idea that big tech firms' share prices will soon collapse under their own weight."

To some, the sell-off could have been sparked by those viewing the stocks as overvalued.

Helal Miah, an analyst at The Share Centre, says that some stocks could have been dumped for more "old economy" bets that had taken a beating during the pandemic.

"The big question is whether this is just a mini correction or something more significant," he says. "A more material correction may be on the way but I am inclined to think that this is just a modest and healthy adjustment, the main reason being that nothing has fundamentally changed in the last few days."

Tech's 2020 rally is backed up by outsized earnings

Perhaps one of the biggest differences between this year's run on tech and the craze at the turn of the millennium is the fundamentals of the businesses involved.

Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google all report enormous profits and boast extremely strong balance sheets. In the case of Apple, it had more than $200bn in cash on hand at the start of the year. Its profits are huge. Apple reported more than $11bn in profit in the second quarter, Microsoft $11.6bn, Amazon $5.2bn.

In the case of many of the biggest stocks they also hold massive market shares that border on near-monopolies in many cases.

When you look at the current price-to-earnings ratios of Big Tech giants now, relative to what was happening during the dot com era, the difference is clear. This chart from Capital Economics shows that while Big Tech's price-to-earnings has grown, it is still relatively stable.

And fundamentally, most of these technology giants have had extremely robust profits for years. Unlike in 2000, when almost all internet stocks were minnows, many of them with no revenues or profits to speak of.

The coronavirus has also driven a lot of growth in tech companies as more and more people began working remotely. Companies like messaging app Slack and videoconferencing software Zoom became even more popular as tools that kept working life alive shot to prominence.

Big Tech's fundamentals were undoubtedly a key driver for SoftBank's decision to jump in on options. There were suggestions that the investment giant had a large hand in the sterling year for tech that caused tech stocks to balloon. SoftBank's oversized bid in a way may have been in keeping with tech's oversized profits.

Markets are expecting even more stimulus from central banks

Dropping a motherload of cash has been the go to for many financial regulators across the world in the hope of getting economies back on track.

On Thursday, the French government unveiled a (EURO)100bn, four-year stimulus package in an effort to boost the economy and keep the recovery moving. In the US this week, the S&P 500 index was boosted by suggestions that Treasury secretary Steve Mnuchin was in talks over the extension of its support scheme for the unemployed.

The European Central Bank has also indicated its desire to help lift the region's economy with massive bond purchases.

In a post, ForexLive's Adam Button was bullish about the continuation of the tech rally due to the varying stimulus measures that are likely to be introduced. "The bottom line is this: the pandemic will end in 2021 but easy money policies from central banks and governments won't," he says.

Around 2000, there had been similar stimulus injections due to fears over the Y2K bug. However, this abruptly trailed off, leaving overvalued tech stocks caught in the open.

Richard Windsor, an independent analyst at RadioFreeMobile, agrees. He says: "The Fed still has its pedal to the metal in terms of stoking the market and while this is going on a full blown reassertion of reality remains unlikely."

All of this means that Wednesday's sell-off looks more like investors de-risking and cashing in their chips rather than identifying fundamental flaws with the world's largest tech businesses.

urn:contentItem:4790-C010-01D0-3121-00000-00Three Republicans compete for Kitzenberg's House seat2000-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:36ZLexisNexisELECTION 2000; Pg. 8EThree Republicans compete for Kitzenberg's House seatEric J. Greene, Staff

By ERIC J. GREENE Tribune Hi-Line Bureau

Three Republicans are vying for the state House of Representatives seat left open by Rep. Sam Kitzenberg, R-Glasgow, who will switch to the state Senate after an uncontested campaign this year.

Lee Humbert and Timothy Tharp, both of Scobey, and Karl Waitschies of Peerless want their party's nomination for House District 96 and the chance to face Democrat Todd Wagner of Glasgow in the November general election.

HD96 is an agriculture-based, 2,462-square-mile region that covers Valley and Daniels counties in northeast Montana.

The Republican primary race has been relatively low key.

Humbert and Waitschies, both farmers, say their spring farm obligations have prevented them from doing much door-to-door campaigning.

They're hoping their reputations as responsible farm operators and local advertising in the two-county district will carry them.

Tharp, a public high school teacher, is counting on his education expertise.

Humbert claims Montana's most pressing need is an economic revival and, as he says, "it's time for the state government to become part of the solution."

"We've got to open Montana up for business and do something to stimulate it so there is a future for people here," Humbert said. "Everybody gets so excited about the big tech companies. But I think a lot of our growth is going to be in small companies. You've got to make it so the five- and 20-employee companies can make a go of it."

In addition to having an efficient tax code that competes with neighboring states, Humbert would like the state to provide 70 percent of public school funding to ease the burdens of local property owners.

"We have some pretty competent school boards, and I'd like to see them get that money and not get a bunch more state regulations or mandates," Humbert said.

Tharp contends his top priority is to protect small school districts around the state that have struggled with tight budgets and shrinking student numbers.

He'd like to alter the school funding formula so money isn't dependent solely on enrollment.

"Schools are the heart of the community, and if the school loses, the community loses," said Tharp, who wants the state to provide base funds each year so districts know in advance how much they're getting.

On economic development, Tharp said he'd work to lower property taxes further and cut red tape for businesses that might add value to the state's agriculture industry.

He also said he'd like to see more cash grants and low-interest loans awarded to value-added companies.

Waitschies noted the steps toward economic development taken last month by the state Legislature were healthy, but didn't go far enough.

He suggests increasing the pot of money for low-interest business loans and implementing a tax-credit system for startup companies.

"We just need to sell the state. If you get out of this area, what we're known for is Freemen and mad bombers, and it's kind of hard to have a corporation come in here unless we do sell the image of a good state," Waitschies said.

On other issues, Waitschies would like to use budget surpluses to fund education and cut property taxes.

He'd also like to impose a 10 percent tax on mineral rights, which currently are not taxed, and reduce property taxes for land owners who do not control their mineral rights.

Timothy Tharp

Home: Scobey.

Employment: Government and math teacher at Scobey High School. Tharp also owns a DJ business, is Daniels County Weed District Supervisor and does sports broadcasting for KCGM Radio.

Education: Master's in mathematics from MSU-Bozeman, 1999; bachelor's in mathematics and history from MSU-Bozeman in 1993.

Political experience: None.
